question: When can the Regulator tell a Fund Manager to change the name of a Fund or Sub-Fund, and what must happen if the name is not suitable?
answer: The Regulator can instruct a Fund Manager to change the name of a Fund or Sub-Fund if it believes the name is not suitable. This might happen if the name is misleading, undesirable, or too similar to another Fund's name. The process starts when the Regulator decides that the name is problematic. Once this decision is made, the Regulator can officially direct the Fund Manager to change the name to avoid any confusion or misleading information. This ensures that all Fund names are clear and do not cause misunderstandings in the market. The Fund Manager must then follow this direction and make the necessary changes to the name. This procedure helps maintain transparency and trust in financial dealings by ensuring that Fund names are distinct and appropriate [#SRC:bdb691fd-fde8-4cef-b9ca-5c2166f72295] and [#TGT:3ec1d30f-39dd-4b93-86ed-4f8e25d7d0ff].
source_passage_text: Pursuant to Section 117 of FSMR, the Regulator has the power to make a direction if a name of a Fund, Sub-Fund or class of Units in a Fund is undesirable, misleading or conflicts with a name used by another Fund, Sub-Fund or class of Units of a Fund.
target_passage_text: Power to make a Direction If, in the opinion of the Regulator, the name of a Fund or of a Sub Fund conflicts with the name of another Fund or Sub-Fund or is undesirable or misleading, it may direct the Fund Manager to change the name of the Fund or the Sub Fund.

question: What actions must an Authorised Person refrain from if it fails to meet the Combined Buffer Requirement, and what must it do before undertaking any distribution of profits?
answer: An Authorised Person that fails to meet the Combined Buffer Requirement is prohibited from undertaking certain actions until it has calculated the maximum distributable amount and notified the Regulator. Specifically, it must not make distributions related to CET1 Capital, create obligations for variable remuneration or discretionary pension benefits, or make payments on AT1 and T2 Capital instruments. Before proceeding with any distribution of profits, the Authorised Person must notify the Regulator and provide detailed information, including the amount of capital maintained, subdivided into CET1, AT1, and T2 Capital, as well as the amount of interim and year-end profits. Additionally, the maximum distributable amount must be calculated, and the intended allocation of distributable profits between dividend payments, share buybacks, payments on AT1 Capital instruments, and variable remuneration or discretionary pension benefits must be disclosed. This ensures compliance with regulatory requirements and prevents unauthorized distributions [#SRC:30965fe8-bf1e-44f4-9cd5-7e9b5f84a81e] [#TGT:e6d646b8-b830-4640-a03e-fabef741c603].
source_passage_text: Restrictions on distributions. Where an Authorised Person fails to meet the Combined Buffer Requirement, it must: (a) calculate the maximum distributable amount in accordance with Rule 3.19.6; and (b) ensure that it does not undertake any of the following actions until such time as it has calculated the maximum distributable amount and notified the Regulator under Rule 3.19.7: (i) make a distribution in connection with CET1 Capital, or create an obligation to pay variable remuneration or discretionary pension benefits, or pay variable remuneration if the obligation to pay was created at a time when the institution failed to meet its Combined Buffer Requirement; or (ii) make payments on AT1 and T2 Capital instruments.
target_passage_text: Restrictions on distributions. For the purpose of Rule 3.19.3(b), where an Authorised Person intends to distribute any of its distributable profits or intends to undertake an action referred to in Rule 3.19.3(b)(i) or (ii), the Authorised Person must notify the Regulator and provide the following information: (a) the amount of capital maintained by the Authorised Person, subdivided as follows: (i) CET1 Capital; (ii) AT1 Capital; and (iii) T2 Capital; (b) the amount of its interim and year-end profits; (c) the maximum distributable amount calculated in accordance with Rule 3.19.6; and (d) the amount of distributable profits it intends to allocate between the following: (i) dividend payments; (ii) Share buybacks; (iii) payments on AT1 Capital instruments; and (iv) the payment of variable remuneration or discretionary pension benefits, whether by creation of a new obligation to pay, or by payment pursuant to an obligation to pay created at a time when the institution failed to meet its Combined Buffer Requirement.

question: What must the Board and its committees of a Reporting Entity and a Listed Entity do to have the right mix of skills and resources?
answer: The Board and its committees for both a Reporting Entity and a Listed Entity must ensure they have the right mix of skills, experience, independence, and knowledge about their business. This is important to make sure they can govern effectively. They also need to have enough resources, like access to experts and up-to-date information about the entity's activities. This is part of Principle 3, which focuses on having a well-balanced Board with the necessary tools to do its job well. For a Reporting Entity, the annual report should also list key roles like the chairman and chief executive and explain which decisions are made by the Board and which are handled by Senior Management. These steps help make sure the Board can oversee the entity properly [#SRC:35277484-31bd-49fe-956c-02f3ceff5405] and [#TGT:705e3965-3995-437d-abe7-8af619b6bbbb].
source_passage_text: Chairman and Chief Executive. The annual report of the Reporting Entity should: a. identify the chairman, the deputy chairman (where there is one), the Directors and the chief executive; and b. include a high level statement of which types of decisions are to be taken by the Board and which are to be delegated to the Senior Management. Principle 3 Board composition and resources Rule 9.2.5 "The Board and its committees must have an appropriate balance of skills, experience, independence and knowledge of the Reporting Entity's business, and adequate resources, including access to expertise as required and timely and comprehensive information relating to the affairs of the Reporting Entity."
target_passage_text: Principle 3 – Board composition and resources. The Board, and its committees, must have an appropriate balance of skills, experience, independence and knowledge of the Listed Entity's business, and adequate resources, including access to expertise as required and timely and comprehensive information relating to the affairs of the Listed Entity.

question: Under what circumstances may an Investigator require a person to provide assistance, and what procedural steps must be followed to ensure compliance with such a requirement?
answer: An Investigator is empowered to require a person to provide assistance in relation to an investigation, as outlined in the relevant regulatory framework. This authority extends to requiring a person to perform physical acts or furnish information that advances the investigation. Procedurally, the Investigator must issue a written notice to the individual, who may be the Person Under Investigation or any other person, regardless of their connection to the investigation. The notice can mandate attendance at an interview, the production of documents, or the provision of necessary information. Additionally, the Investigator may require the person to permit entry to business premises for document inspection and copying during normal business hours. These procedural steps ensure that the Investigator's powers are exercised within the defined scope and that the required assistance is obtained in a structured manner [#SRC:c595f91e-fb49-45e1-9dd6-7a847f54df95] [#TGT:ba9deea1-694d-4225-bf79-201773a12046].
source_passage_text: Power to require assistance. Section 206(1)(d) of FSMR empowers the Investigator to require a person to provide assistance in relation to an investigation, which may include requiring a person to do a physical act or provide information to advance an investigation. For example, an Investigator may require a person to assist in the location of specific documents.
target_passage_text: The Investigator may, by written notice, require the person who is the Person Under Investigation or any other person (whether or not connected to the Person Under Investigation) to— (a) attend an interview at a Specified time and place and answer questions; (b) produce at a Specified time and place any Specified Documents or Documents of a Specified description; (c) provide such information as the Investigator may require; (d) provide such assistance as the Investigator may require; or (e) permit the Investigator to enter the business premises of such person during normal business hours for the purpose of inspecting and copying Documents on such premises.

question: Under what conditions may a Recognised Investment Exchange operate a Multilateral Trading Facility, and what stipulations must be included in its Recognition Order?
answer: A Recognised Investment Exchange may carry on the Regulated Activity of operating an MTF or OTF provided that its Recognition Order includes a stipulation permitting it to do so. This stipulation is crucial as it allows the exchange to engage in these activities. Once the stipulation is included, the specific rules on MTFs and OTFs in COBS will apply to that function, ensuring compliance with regulatory standards. Additionally, if the Recognised Investment Exchange is operating an MTF using Virtual Assets, it must adhere to the requirements of the Virtual Asset Framework. This ensures that while the exchange is permitted to operate an MTF or OTF, it must do so within the boundaries set by both the Recognition Order and the applicable regulatory frameworks, maintaining a high standard of compliance across its operations [#SRC:54b67759-66a7-4cbd-a335-1a40ee4894bb] and [#TGT:8e498a69-8f0c-44c3-970c-58d870656388].
source_passage_text: MULTILATERAL TRADING FACILITIES AND VIRTUAL ASSETS Recognised Investment Exchanges Operating an MTF using Virtual Assets Pursuant to MIR Rule 3.4.1, a Recognised Investment Exchange may operate an MTF, provided that its Recognition Order includes a stipulation permitting it to do so. MIR Rule 3.4.2 requires that where such a stipulation is granted to a Recognised Investment Exchange, the Recognised Investment Exchange must meet the requirements of the Virtual Asset Framework in relation to operation of an MTF (using Virtual Assets) while the remainder of its operations must be operated in compliance with the MIR Rules.
target_passage_text: A Recognised Investment Exchange may carry on the Regulated Activity of operating an MTF or OTF provided that its Recognition Order includes a stipulation permitting it to do so. If it does include such a stipulation, the specific rules on MTFs and OTFs in COBS will apply to that function, but that function only.

question: What must a Mining Reporting Entity ensure when preparing disclosures about Exploration Targets or similar statements to fully comply with binding requirements?
answer: A Mining Reporting Entity must ensure that any disclosure including statements about Exploration Targets, Exploration Results, Mineral Resources, Ore Reserves, or Production Targets is prepared in accordance with a Mining Reporting Standard as well as the relevant chapter. This dual compliance is necessary to fully meet all binding requirements set out in the applicable standards. The Regulator mandates adherence to both mandatory and non-mandatory requirements of the Mining Reporting Standard, such as those found in the JORC Code or SAMREC Code, unless an explanation for non-compliance is provided. This comprehensive approach ensures that all disclosures are not only aligned with the technical standards but also with the overarching regulatory framework, thereby maintaining the integrity and reliability of the information presented by the Mining Reporting Entity [#SRC:b8235755-7447-4ae5-b3dc-8cb14109c124] and [#TGT:5d4c0697-2ff8-49a4-9682-8e63acb63b9d].
source_passage_text: Rule 11.2.1(1) requires a Mining Reporting Entity to fully comply with all binding requirements set out in a Mining Reporting Standard. The Regulator also expects a Mining Reporting Entity to fully comply with all non-mandatory requirements set out in a Mining Reporting Standard, including, for example, Table 1 of the JORC Code or SAMREC Code, or explain its non-compliance in accordance with Rule 11.2.2.
target_passage_text: Requirements for all disclosures. A disclosure by a Mining Reporting Entity that includes a statement about Exploration Targets, Exploration Results, Mineral Resources, Ore Reserves or Production Targets must be prepared in accordance with: (1) a Mining Reporting Standard; and (2) this chapter.

question: How can a Remote Body ask the Regulator to change or skip a notification rule, and when can a Recognised Body get permission for the same?
answer: A Remote Body can ask the Regulator to change or skip a notification rule by applying for a waiver. The steps they need to follow are the same as those for Recognised Bodies, which are detailed in the rules. For a Recognised Body, the Regulator can allow changes or waivers to notification rules if the body applies or gives consent. This means the Regulator can decide that a rule doesn’t apply or applies differently, based on what they specify. Any changes or waivers given by the Regulator might come with certain conditions. This process helps both Remote and Recognised Bodies to adjust rules when needed, while still following the main regulatory guidelines [#SRC:ca1afb04-05dc-47a6-bee3-1d7d32394400] and [#TGT:08895e4b-f6d8-4da1-a4be-1cf89c6bfd48].
source_passage_text: Waivers . Remote Bodies may apply to the Regulator for a waiver of any of the notification rules. The procedure is the same as that for applications from Recognised Bodies, as set out in Rule 5.3.1.
target_passage_text: The Regulator may, on the application or with the consent of a Recognised Body, direct that any notification rule is not to apply to the body or is to apply with such modifications as it may specify. Any such waiver or modification granted by the Regulator may be made subject to conditions.

question: When does an Authorised Person running a Multilateral or Organised Trading Facility need to hold specific regulatory capital, and what steps are involved for Accepted Spot Commodities?
answer: An Authorised Person managing a Multilateral Trading Facility (MTF) or an Organised Trading Facility (OTF) needs to hold specific regulatory capital when they are involved in activities related to Accepted Spot Commodities. The FSRA requires these facilities to maintain capital equivalent to six months of their operational expenses. This is part of the broader capital requirements procedures found in MIR 3.2, which apply to all activities related to Spot Commodities conducted by the Authorised Person. Additionally, any mention of a 'Recognised Investment Exchange' in these procedures should be understood as referring to an 'Authorised Person.' This ensures that the rules are applied correctly and consistently, helping to manage financial risks and maintain stability in the market. By following these steps, Authorised Persons ensure they have the necessary financial backing to support their trading activities and comply with regulatory standards [#SRC:59dfe046-0591-4dc2-a1d3-f4b1d56e6ee8] and [#TGT:e2bf9346-3c58-487a-b818-3e130b1f7365].
source_passage_text: REGULATORY REQUIREMENTS - SPOT COMMODITY ACTIVITIES Capital Requirements The FSRA applies the regulatory capital requirements in COBS Rule 22.10 in two different scenarios, such that: a) where the Authorised Person is an MTF or OTF, the regulatory capital to be held (under COBS Rule 22.10.1(a) and MIR Rule 3.2.1) is equivalent to 6 months operational expenses ; and b) in relation to all other Authorised Persons, the conventional regulatory capital requirements applicable to the Regulated Activities undertaken apply.
target_passage_text: Where an Authorised Person is conducting: (a) the Regulated Activity of Operating a Multilateral Trading Facility or the Regulated Activity of Operating an Organised Trading Facility in relation to Accepted Spot Commodities, the capital requirements set out in MIR 3.2 (Capital Requirements) shall apply to all the Regulated Activities undertaken by the Authorised Person in relation to Spot Commodities; and (b) For the purposes of this Rule, all references in MIR 3.2 to a “Recognised Investment Exchange” shall be read as references to an “Authorised Person”.

question: If an Authorised Person wants to use Collateral for CRM, what must they do to meet the rules, and what types of financial Collateral are considered eligible under the FCCA?
answer: An Authorised Person must follow the relevant requirements in Rule 4.13.8 to use Collateral for Credit Risk Mitigation (CRM) effectively. This involves making sure they meet specific rules to recognise the effects of CRM for the types of Collateral listed in Rules 4.13.5 to 4.13.7. At the same time, under the FCCA, eligible financial Collateral includes instruments listed in Rule 4.13.5, equity Securities traded on a regulated exchange, and Units in a Collective Investment Fund that invests in these Securities. For the Fund's Units to be eligible, their price must be publicly quoted daily, and at least 90% of the Fund's assets must be in the specified instruments. By ensuring compliance with these rules and understanding what qualifies as eligible financial Collateral, Authorised Persons can effectively manage credit risk and adhere to regulatory standards [#SRC:c36bf3cf-160f-43ab-bb40-9d7f5ceec7b8] [#TGT:2d7f3106-4761-4113-abe3-580e52ee1c85].
source_passage_text: Collateral In order to recognise the effects of CRM of the types of Collateral set out in Rules 4.13.5 to 4.13.7, an Authorised Person must ensure that the relevant requirements in Rule 4.13.8 are complied with.
target_passage_text: For an Authorised Person using the FCCA, eligible financial Collateral comprises: (a) any instrument listed in Rule 4.13.5; (b) any equity Security (including a convertible bond) that is traded on a regulated exchange; and (c) any Unit in a Collective Investment Fund which invests in equity Securities referred to in (b), where: (i) a price for the Units is publicly quoted daily; and (ii) at least 90% of the deposited property of the Fund is invested in instruments listed in this Rule and Rule 4.13.5.

question: When does an Authorised Person not have to calculate its Foreign Exchange Risk Capital Requirement, considering its exposure to foreign currencies and gold and its Foreign Currency business size?
answer: An Authorised Person must calculate its Foreign Exchange Risk Capital Requirement if it is exposed to foreign currencies and gold under any Islamic Contract. However, it does not need to do this calculation if its Foreign Currency business, which is the greater of its total long or short positions in all Foreign Currencies, is not more than 100% of its Capital Resources. Also, it is exempt if its overall net open position is not more than 2% of its Capital Resources. These rules mean that only those with larger exposures need to calculate the requirement, making it easier for smaller businesses to comply [#SRC:6a51fe1f-d0d3-42f6-b369-4e9345775696] and [#TGT:79d3cd2f-93a5-4f25-af68-c67e7fd4cb97].
source_passage_text: Market risk. An Authorised Person which is exposed to the risk of foreign currencies and gold under any Islamic Contract, must calculate its Foreign Exchange Risk Capital Requirement in accordance with PRU Rule 5.6.2.
target_passage_text: An Authorised Person need not calculate a Foreign Exchange Risk Capital Requirement if: (a) its Foreign Currency business, defined as the greater of the sum of its gross long positions and the sum of its gross short positions in all Foreign Currencies, does not exceed 100% of Capital Resources as defined in Chapter 3; and (b) its overall net open position as defined in Rule A6.4.4 does not exceed 2% of its Capital Resources as defined in Chapter 3.

question: When can an Authorised Person use delivery and storage facilities for Accepted Spot Commodities, and what rules must these facilities follow?
answer: An Authorised Person can only use delivery and storage facilities for Accepted Spot Commodities if these facilities are located within the Abu Dhabi Global Market (ADGM) or in jurisdictions that meet certain criteria. If the facilities are outside the ADGM, they must follow rules similar to those in the ADGM. They also need to comply with all relevant local and international laws, including those related to ports, customs, anticorruption, and taxes. The facilities should meet international standards for storage and delivery, have health and safety certifications, and maintain strong audit and control systems. They must also have insurance to cover risks like fraud and natural disasters. These requirements ensure that the facilities are safe and compliant with necessary regulations [#SRC:4230a066-37c4-4630-bb93-d9a0ed5bc81b] and [#TGT:dda13926-2cce-4e09-a50f-508bd4257bd5].
source_passage_text: An Authorised Person, and its participants, must only use delivery and/or storage facilities for Accepted Spot Commodities from: (a) within the ADGM, or (b) other appropriate jurisdictions that can meet the requirements of Rule 22.4.2.
target_passage_text: For the purposes of Rule 22.4.1, any delivery and/or storage facility used by an Authorised Person must be a facility in relation to which – (a) where the delivery and/or storage facility operates from outside ADGM, it operates under rules and regulations equivalent to those applying in the Abu Dhabi Global Market; (b) the delivery and/or storage facility will, at all times, comply with all applicable laws in the relevant jurisdiction or elsewhere, including in particular and without limitation: (i) local port conditions; (ii) local, national and global customs requirements; (iii) local, national and global anticorruption laws; (iv) local, national and global taxation requirements; and (v) any other applicable rules and regulations; (c) the delivery and/or storage facility adheres to: (i) appropriate international standards for storage and delivery mechanisms, including with regard to IOSCO’s Good and Sound Practices; and (ii) OHSAS 18001 Health & Safety Management or equivalent certification standards; (d) it has appropriate audit and control arrangements in place, in relation to inventories, deliveries and physical infrastructure; and (e) it has appropriate insurance arrangements in place to cover operational, security, fraud, natural disasters and other applicable risks.

question: If a Mining Reporting Entity thinks its economic assumptions are sensitive, what must it say in its report, and how should it explain the way it figured out these assumptions?
answer: When a Mining Reporting Entity believes its economic assumptions are sensitive, it must state this in its report. The entity should explain why the information is considered sensitive or a trade secret. It also needs to provide enough details, possibly using words instead of numbers if the numbers are sensitive, so investors can understand how it came up with these assumptions and the basis for its Ore Reserves estimates. This approach ensures that while protecting sensitive information, the entity still gives investors a clear understanding of the methodology and assumptions involved, as required [#TGT:6435d936-1f1e-44c9-a788-2a4f4de44b80] and permitted [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489].
source_passage_text: A Mining Reporting Entitys disclosure pursuant to Rule 11.9.1 must include: (1) in relation to the assumptions used to determine the forecast financial information: (a) all material economic assumptions employed; (b) if the Mining Reporting Entity considers the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive, a statement to that effect and an explanation of the methodology used to determine the material economic assumptions; and Guidance A Mining Reporting Entity that considers certain information relating to the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive should refer to paragraphs 47-54 of the Guidance on Mining and paragraphs 127 and 128 of the Guidance on Continuous Disclosure. (c) all other material assumptions utilised. (2) the Production Target from which the forecast financial information is derived (including all the information contained in Rule 11.8.3).
target_passage_text: ORE RESERVES. In such cases, however, where a Mining Reporting Entity relies on the guidance set out in Rule 11.6.1(1)(a), it: a) must make a statement to the effect that its material economic assumptions are commercially sensitive; b) should explain why the information is considered a trade secret or commercially sensitive; and c) must disclose sufficient information (possibly in narrative rather than numerical form, where the numbers are commercially sensitive) in order for investors to understand the methodology it has used to determine these factors and assumptions, and the basis on which it is reporting the estimates of Ore Reserves.

question: How should an MTF or OTF make sure their public information follows a consistent format, and what does this mean for Recognised Investment Exchanges?
answer: An MTF or OTF must ensure that their public disclosures, including trading information, follow a consistent and structured format. This requirement is similar to what Recognised Investment Exchanges must do, as they also need to make sure that the information they make public is in line with industry standards. Both MTFs, OTFs, and Recognised Investment Exchanges have the freedom to choose the specific format they use, but it must be consistent and structured. This helps ensure that the information is reliable, monitored continuously, and available to the public fairly. By following these guidelines, both types of trading platforms maintain transparency and consistency in how they share information with the public [#SRC:86058b68-1cad-488d-9bd7-2d6bdd750bef] and [#TGT:dd3d6160-82a8-4962-8bbc-287a50285504].
source_passage_text: REGULATORY REQUIREMENTS - SPOT COMMODITY ACTIVITIES Public disclosure Any arrangements of an MTF or OTF used to make information public (including trading information required to be disclosed under MIR Rules 3.5 and 3.6) must satisfy a number of conditions, including that it is reliable, monitored continuously, and made available to the public on a non-discriminatory basis. While an MTF or OTF can choose the format structure to be used for dissemination, MIR Rule 3.7.4 requires it to conform to a consistent and structured format.
target_passage_text: Information that is made public should conform to a consistent and structured format based on industry standards. Recognised Investment Exchanges can choose the structure that they use.

question: What records do PFP Operators have to keep for six years, and what must they publish on their platform for clients?
answer: PFP Operators must keep records for at least six years, including all disclosures, documentation with clients and any corporate bodies they set up, and due diligence activities. At the same time, they must publish important information on their Private Financing Platform. This includes risk statements, confirmation that they don't provide credit or investment advice, and a suggestion for clients to seek independent advice. They also need to share the platform's terms of operation, any conflicts of interest, details of any custodian, and arrangements for winding down operations if needed. Additionally, they must provide details about financing proposals, the criteria for accepting proposals, and the due diligence process. Information about any intermediary corporate bodies, exit facilities, and other relevant roles or obligations must also be available to clients. These requirements ensure that clients have access to all necessary information and that the platform operates transparently [#SRC:94d5a3fb-7438-42dd-8c48-70588f3d0dd7] and [#TGT:1539edbe-2c5c-412f-8872-f359c291a27f].
source_passage_text: A PFP Operator must, for a minimum of six years, maintain and keep a record of: (a) all disclosures made in accordance with Rules 18.5.1 and 18.5.2; (b) all documentation between PFP Client(s), any Body Corporate established by the PFP Operator to facilitate a transaction, and the PFP Prospect; and (c) the due diligence undertaken in accordance with Rule 18.4.1.
target_passage_text: A PFP Operator must ensure that the following information, available to PFP Clients, is published on a Private Financing Platform it operates: (a) a statement identifying the risks involved in participating in financing proposals identified on the Private Financing Platform; (b) a statement confirming that the PFP Operator is not providing credit or investment advice to any PFP Client or PFP Prospect, and advising PFP Clients to seek independent advice prior to entering into any transaction; (c) the terms of operation of the Private Financing Platform, including the PFP Operator’s remuneration model; (d) the details of any potential conflicts of interest between the PFP Operator, PFP Clients and any PFP Prospect; (e) the details of the Eligible Custodian engaged by the PFP Operator, if so appointed; (f) the wind-down arrangements the PFP Operator has in place to ensure the orderly administration of transactions facilitated on the Private Financing Platform it operates in the event of its failure; (g) the details of any financing proposal published on the Private Financing Platform; (h) the criteria and methodology for accepting a PFP Prospect’s financing proposal for publication on a Private Financing Platform; (i) the methodology of, and limitations to, the due diligence undertaken by the PFP Operator concerning each PFP Prospect identified on the Private Financing Platform, in accordance with Rule 18.4.1; (j) the governance and operational arrangements of any Body Corporate used as an intermediary between a PFP Client and any PFP Prospect; (k) the details of the exit facility, if any, that the PFP Operator offers upon the Private Financing Platform, in accordance with Rule 18.8; and (l) any other relevant information concerning the roles or obligations of the PFP Operator that a PFP Client should be aware of.

question: What details about dispute resolution must a Third Party Provider give to Customers, and where should these details be available?
answer: A Third Party Provider must give Customers details about the dispute resolution services that can handle disputes about rights and obligations under the relevant Chapter. These details need to be clear, comprehensive, and easy to access. The Provider must ensure this information is available on their website, at their main office and any branches, and included in the general terms and conditions of the Governing Contract. This approach ensures that Customers can easily find and understand the dispute resolution options available to them, meeting the Provider's obligations as required [#TGT:08650621-06b8-481f-8650-2c5ebdb06be0] and permitted [#SRC:055fc91a-22c6-4511-9508-b90212a4d414].
source_passage_text: The information to be made available under Rule 20.13.3 must be made available: (a) on the website of the Third Party Provider; (b) at the main office and any branches of the Third Party Provider; and (c) in the general terms and conditions of the Governing Contract.
target_passage_text: A Third Party Provider must make available to the Customer the details of the dispute resolution services able to deal with disputes concerning the rights and obligations arising under this Chapter in a clear, comprehensive and easily accessible form.

question: What steps must a Relevant Person take before appointing a service provider for CDD, specifically regarding the assurance assessment of an eKYC System?
answer: Prior to appointing a service provider to undertake Customer Due Diligence (CDD), a Relevant Person must conduct an initial assurance assessment to evaluate the service provider's suitability. This assessment should ensure that the eKYC System is reliable, independent, and compliant with all applicable regulatory rules. The Relevant Person is also required to ensure that the service provider's obligations are clearly documented in a binding agreement. Additionally, the Relevant Person should consider applying guidance on assurance standards issued by the Regulator, competent U.A.E. authorities, FATF, and other relevant standard-setting bodies. This comprehensive approach ensures that the service provider is capable of fulfilling its obligations effectively and that the eKYC System supports compliance with regulatory requirements [#SRC:611c820f-2988-4e25-9091-4a3b299501b4] and [#TGT:1f815e39-1a9b-4f7d-af18-65b633fed752].
source_passage_text: When undertaking an assurance assessment of an eKYC System for the purpose of Rule 9.3.1A, a Relevant Person should seek to establish that the eKYC System is reliable and independent, and allows the Relevant Person to comply with all applicable Rules of the Regulator. In addition, a Relevant Person should consider applying guidance on assurance standards issued by the Regulator, competent U.A.E. authorities, FATF, and other relevant standard setting bodies.
target_passage_text: Prior to appointing a service provider to undertake CDD, a Relevant Person must undertake an initial assurance assessment to evaluate the suitability of the service provider and must ensure that the service provider's obligations are clearly documented in a binding agreement.

question: Under what conditions may an Authorised Person treat Exposures as collateralised, and how does the definition of eligible financial Collateral under the FCCA relate to these conditions?
answer: An Authorised Person may treat Exposures as collateralised only if the specific conditions outlined in the relevant rules concerning Credit Risk Mitigation (CRM) are satisfied. These conditions include the recognition of certain financial instruments and agreements, such as cash received under a Credit Linked Note (CLN) issued by the Authorised Person, and loans and deposits of a Counterparty subject to an on-balance sheet Netting agreement. In relation to the FCCA, eligible financial Collateral includes instruments listed in the applicable rules, equity securities traded on regulated exchanges, and units in Collective Investment Funds that invest predominantly in such securities. The definition of eligible financial Collateral is crucial as it determines what can be considered as collateral under the FCCA, thereby impacting the Authorised Person's ability to treat Exposures as collateralised. This interplay ensures that only those Exposures backed by recognised and eligible collateral can be treated as such, aligning with the regulatory framework for managing credit risk [#SRC:558596ee-af40-4c07-8067-9c5c25eebaa5] and [#TGT:2d7f3106-4761-4113-abe3-580e52ee1c85].
source_passage_text: An Authorised Person can only treat Exposures as collateralised provided the conditions of Rules 4.13.5 to 4.13.8 (relating to CRM) are met. Item (d) also includes cash received under a CLN issued by the Authorised Person and loans and Deposits of a Counterparty to or with the Authorised Person which are subject to an on balance sheet Netting agreement recognised under Section 4.13 (CRM).
target_passage_text: For an Authorised Person using the FCCA, eligible financial Collateral comprises: (a) any instrument listed in Rule 4.13.5; (b) any equity Security (including a convertible bond) that is traded on a regulated exchange; and (c) any Unit in a Collective Investment Fund which invests in equity Securities referred to in (b), where: (i) a price for the Units is publicly quoted daily; and (ii) at least 90% of the deposited property of the Fund is invested in instruments listed in this Rule and Rule 4.13.5.

question: When can a Regulator let a party managing a holding lock release it during a takeover, and what must a Listed Entity do about the holding lock soon after issuing Restricted Securities?
answer: A Regulator can allow a party managing a holding lock to release it during a takeover or merger, which helps holders of Restricted Securities accept offers or transfer or cancel their securities. This is possible if the party follows certain rules. At the same time, a Listed Entity must get an agreement from a suitable entity, like a bank or custodian, to put a holding lock on the Restricted Securities. This agreement must be submitted to the Regulator within two business days after the securities are issued. The holding lock cannot be removed without the Regulator's written consent. This ensures that the securities remain restricted unless the Regulator decides otherwise, providing a balance between regulatory control and the needs of transactions like takeovers [#SRC:12178c65-d1b6-440a-91e1-c670c7d9ab67] and [#TGT:6e593960-67c1-4a79-90d0-161055303d76].
source_passage_text: Regulators consent to sale of Restricted Securities in a Takeover or Merger. The Regulator may consent to a party that is managing a holding lock in accordance with Rule 9.6.9 releasing the holding lock, to enable holders of Restricted Securities to accept an offer, or transfer or cancel Securities, under a Takeover.
target_passage_text: Timing and Enforcement. A Listed Entity must obtain, and submit to the Regulator, within two Business Days after the issue of Restricted Securities, an undertaking from a bank, trustee, custodian, Recognised Body, CSD or other entity deemed suitable by the Regulator, to place a holding lock on the Restricted Securities held by it, and not to release the holding lock without the Regulator’s prior written consent.

question: What must a Relevant Person think about when checking if another place's AML/TFS rules match FATF standards, and how does this connect to using a Group member for CDD tasks?
answer: When a Relevant Person checks if another place's AML/TFS rules match FATF standards, they must think about things like international evaluations, membership in groups like FATF, and the political situation in that place. This is important when a Relevant Person uses a Group member to do parts of Customer Due Diligence (CDD) for them. The Group member doesn't have to meet some conditions if the Group follows rules similar to FATF standards and has a Group-wide policy on CDD and record-keeping. Also, the Group's CDD and AML/TFS programs should be checked by a competent authority in a place with similar rules. This makes sure that using the Group member is okay and follows international standards, keeping the CDD process strong [#SRC:06794d47-81ee-49d0-bf3a-58e87a031da4] and [#TGT:32b078c5-682a-457e-9d94-482e8a9af33e].
source_passage_text: When assessing under Rule 9.1.1(3) or (4) if AML/TFS regulations in another jurisdiction are equivalent to FATF standards, a Relevant Person must take into account factors including, but not limited to: (a) mutual evaluations, assessment reports or follow-up reports published by FATF, the IMF, the World Bank, the OECD or other International Organisations; (b) membership of FATF or other international or regional groups such as the MENAFATF or the Gulf Co-operation Council; (c) contextual factors such as political stability or the level of corruption in the jurisdiction; (d) evidence of recent criticism of the jurisdiction, including in: (i) FATF advisory notices; (ii) public assessments of the jurisdictions AML/TFS regimes by organisations referred to in (a); or (iii) reports by other relevant non-government organisations or specialist commercial organisations; (e) whether adequate arrangements exist for co-operation between the AML/TFS regulator in that jurisdiction and the Regulator.
target_passage_text: Where a Relevant Person relies on a member of its Group to conduct one or more of the elements of CDD on its behalf, such Group member need not meet the condition in (3)(c) if: (a) the Group is subject to policies and requirements equivalent to FATF standards, either: (i) where the Group applies and implements a Group-wide policy on CDD and record-keeping which is equivalent to the standards set by FATF; or (ii) where the effective implementation of those CDD and record-keeping requirements and AML/TFS programmes are supervised at Group level by a Non-ADGM Financial Services Regulator or other competent authority in a jurisdiction with AML/TFS regulations that are equivalent to the standards set out in the FATF Recommendations; (b) no exception from identification obligations has been applied in the original identification process; and (c) a written statement is received from the introducing member of the Relevant Person's Group confirming that: (i) the customer has been identified in accordance with the relevant standards under (4)(a) and (b); (ii) any identification evidence can be accessed by the Relevant Person without delay; and (iii) the identification evidence will be kept for at least six years.

question: Under what circumstances must an Insider not disclose Inside Information to another person, considering both the improper disclosure examples and the prohibition on disclosure outside the proper course of duties?
answer: An Insider must not disclose Inside Information to another person if the disclosure occurs outside the proper course of their employment, profession, or duties. This prohibition is crucial to maintaining market integrity and preventing unfair advantages. For instance, the Regulator provides examples where such disclosure is improper, such as a Director sharing confidential takeover information with a friend who has no connection to the company, or a CEO informing family members about significant financial disclosures before they are made public. These actions contravene the prohibition because they involve sharing sensitive information with individuals who are not entitled to it in the course of the Insider's professional responsibilities. The prohibition ensures that Inside Information is not used for personal gain or to benefit others improperly, thereby upholding the principles of fairness and transparency in the market [#SRC:95f79fc9-f00f-4f1f-a811-683ca34ed4a1] and [#TGT:24c9495c-026d-446e-865a-9051fa94f13b].
source_passage_text: Examples of improper disclosure of Inside Information. The following are specific examples of conduct that, in the Regulator's view, may contravene section 92(3): (a) A, a Director of a Company (an Authorised Person) has lunch with a friend, B, who has no connection with the Company or its advisers. A tells B that his Company has received a Takeover Offer that is at a premium to the current share price at which it is trading; (b) B is the CEO of a Company (an Authorised Person) that is about to release its annual financial report. The report will disclose an outstanding claim that will have a significant impact on the Company's financial results. B passes the information on to family members (who have no role in the Company); (c) an Officer or Employee of an Issuer selectively briefs analysts about developments relating to the Issuer that have not yet been disclosed to the market; and (d) the chairman of an Authorised Person announces his resignation to a journalist before this information has been disclosed to the market as a whole.
target_passage_text: The second is where an Insider discloses Inside Information to another person otherwise than in the proper course of the exercise of his employment, profession or duties.

question: If a Key Individual stops working in their role, what must a Recognised Body do to keep up with its rules about telling the Regulator and having the right people in place?
answer: If a Key Individual stops working in their role, the Recognised Body must inform the Regulator in writing within ten Business Days. This is important to follow the rules properly. At the same time, the Recognised Body needs to make sure it still has the right Key Individuals in place. These roles include important positions like Members of the Governing Body, Senior Executive Officer, and others such as the Chief Compliance Officer and Money Laundering Reporting Officer. The Recognised Body must have these roles filled by one or more people at all times to do its job right. This means they have to quickly handle any changes in who is in these roles and make sure they always have the necessary people in place as required [#TGT:8a67244a-a157-496e-8caf-1cf714889bfa] and permitted [#SRC:c5e80704-d530-4e85-a790-1d2e3f85b498].
source_passage_text: In circumstances where an individual who has been approved as a Key Individual pursuant to Rule 2.3.5 will no longer act as a Key Individual, whether by resignation, withdrawal or variation, the Recognised Body must notify the Regulator in writing within ten Business Days of such resignation, withdrawal or variation, and ensure it continues to satisfy Rule 2.3.2.
target_passage_text: Key Individuals. A Recognised Body must, for the purposes of the proper discharge of its Regulatory Functions, appoint the following Key Individuals, where deemed necessary and required by the Regulator, ensuring that they are held by one or more individuals at all times: (a) Members of the Governing Body; (b) Senior Executive Officer; (c) Finance Officer; (d) Chief Operating Officer; (e) Chief Technology Officer; (f) Chief Information Security Officer; (g) Head of Market Supervision; (h) Chief Compliance Officer (i) Money Laundering Reporting Officer; and (j) Chief Risk Officer.

question: Under what conditions does Price Stabilisation not constitute Market Abuse, and how must it be carried out to ensure compliance with the relevant regulations?
answer: Price Stabilisation does not constitute Market Abuse when it is conducted in accordance with the specific Rules outlined in the regulations. Specifically, if a Person can establish that their Price Stabilisation activities are carried out in accordance with the MKT 6.2 Rules, this conduct will not contravene section 92. The Rules under MKT 6.2 provide the necessary guidelines that must be adhered to for such activities to be deemed compliant. Furthermore, the regulations clarify that Behaviour does not amount to Market Abuse if it conforms with a Rule that explicitly states that such Behaviour is not considered Market Abuse. Additionally, compliance with the Price Stabilisation Rules ensures that the conduct is within the regulatory framework, thereby exempting it from being classified as Market Abuse. This exemption is crucial for maintaining the integrity of financial markets while allowing for legitimate Price Stabilisation activities to occur without breaching regulatory standards [#SRC:6befa69b-50a0-463a-bf02-9fdaa4ed741e] and [#TGT:89c2648f-fb2a-4194-997f-a5d6d4f074a1].
source_passage_text: Price Stabilisation. The effect of section 93(3)(b) is that if a Person establishes that they carried out Price Stabilisation in accordance with MKT 6.2, this conduct will not contravene section 92. MKT 6.2 sets out the relevant Rules relating to carrying on Price Stabilisation that must be complied with.
target_passage_text: Behaviour does not amount to Market Abuse for the purposes of these Regulations if— (a) it conforms with a Rule which includes a provision to the effect that Behaviour conforming with the Rule does not amount to Market Abuse; (b) it conforms with the Price Stabilisation Rules; or (c) it is done by a person acting on behalf of a public authority in the legitimate exercise of its public functions.

question: What must the Fund Manager of a Passported Fund do when a material event occurs, particularly if the Prospectus has been amended or replaced?
answer: The Fund Manager of a Passported Fund must notify the Regulator as soon as practicable of any material events, in accordance with applicable ADGM legislation. This notification must include reasonable detail of the event and, if applicable, a copy of the new Prospectus. The notification must adhere to the prescribed form as directed by the Regulator. Specific events requiring notification include changes such as the amendment or replacement of the Prospectus, the retirement or replacement of the Fund Manager, and changes to material service providers. The notification must be made no later than seven days after the Fund Manager becomes aware of the event. This ensures that the Regulator is kept informed of significant changes that may impact the operation or management of the Passported Fund, thereby maintaining regulatory oversight and compliance with ADGM requirements [#SRC:a293c037-9b5d-4128-8318-f840f0264d1f] and [#TGT:7a51b100-c0e6-41bd-809c-d2ae395a9898].
source_passage_text: The notification referred to in Rule 6.6.2 must be in such prescribed form as the Regulator may direct from time to time. At a minimum, the notification must be accompanied by reasonable detail of the event and (where the Prospectus has been amended or replaced) a copy of the new Prospectus.
target_passage_text: The Fund Manager of a Passported Fund must notify the Regulator as soon as practicable of any material events, in accordance with applicable ADGM legislation. In particular (but without limitation), a Fund Manager or the governing body or trustee of a Passported Fund must notify the Regulator as soon as practicable (and in any case no later than seven days after it becomes aware) of any of the following events: (a) the Fund Manager intends to retire as manager of the Passported Fund; (b) it is proposed that a successor manager will be appointed in relation to the Passported Fund; (c) the Fund Manager has been removed or replaced as manager of the Passported Fund; (d) any material service provider to the Passported Fund (including, without limitation, any custodian) or an Agent or Licensed Person resigns, is appointed, is removed, or is replaced; (e) the Prospectus relating to the Passported Fund has been amended or replaced; (f) winding-up of the Passported Fund has commenced; or (g) the Fund Manager intends to vary or revoke its Financial Service Permission (or any conditions contained in that Financial Service Permission).

question: Under what conditions can an Issuer utilize an Exempt Offer that relies on specific circumstances, excluding one particular rule, when seeking admission of Securities to an MTF?
answer: An Issuer seeking to admit its Securities to trading on a Multilateral Trading Facility (MTF) may utilize an Exempt Offer by relying on specific circumstances outlined by the Regulator, with the exception of one particular rule. The Regulator defines an Exempt Offer as one that can be directed at only Professional Clients or under other specified conditions, such as being directed at no more than 50 Persons in a 12-month period, or where the total consideration for the Securities is at least $100,000. However, when an Issuer is making an Exempt Offer in conjunction with an MTF admission, it must exclude reliance on the rule that allows offers to no more than 50 Persons. Instead, the Issuer may make an Exempt Offer to up to 200 Persons who are not Professional Clients, provided the Securities are to be admitted to an MTF. This framework ensures that the Issuer can strategically navigate the regulatory landscape while adhering to the prescribed limitations and conditions for Exempt Offers [#SRC:d2b137bd-19a4-4fb0-aaf3-0dddc7610d42] [#TGT:aebfec36-985e-4d75-a783-f582fed8fafc].
source_passage_text: MKT Rule 4.3.1(13) provides for the specific circumstance where an Exempt Offer can be directed to no more than 200 Persons who do not qualify as Professional Clients, where the Securities are to be admitted to trading on a MTF. An Issuer seeking admission to trading of its Securities on an MTF in accordance with MKT Rule 4.3.1(13) may also, pursuant to MKT Rule 4.3.3, utilise an Exempt Offer that relies on one or more of the circumstances within MKT Rule 4.3.1, with the exception of MKT Rule 4.3.1(2). For example, an Issuer may make a simultaneous Exempt Offer to 200 Persons under MKT rule 4.3.1(13), and an unlimited number of Professional Clients under MKT Rule 4.3.1(1).
target_passage_text: For the purposes of section 61(3)(a) of the FSMR, the Regulator prescribes the following to be circumstances in which an Offer is an Exempt Offer: (1) an Offer made to or directed at only Professional Clients; (2) an Offer in or from the ADGM which is directed at no more than 50 Persons in any 12-month period, excluding Professional Clients who are not natural persons; (3) an Offer where the total consideration to be paid by a Person to acquire the Securities is at least $100,000, or an equivalent amount in another currency; (4) an Offer where the Securities are denominated in amounts of at least $100,000, or an equivalent amount in another currency; (5) an Offer where the total aggregate consideration for the Securities offered is less than $100,000, or an equivalent amount in another currency, calculated over a period of 12 months; (6) an Offer where Shares are issued in substitution for Shares of the same class as already issued, where the issue of the new Shares does not involve any increase in the issued Share capital; (7) an Offer where the Securities are Convertibles issued under a Prospectus to existing members or creditors of the Issuer or a member of its Group and there is no additional consideration to be paid; (8) an Offer where the Securities are offered in connection with a Takeover and a document is made available containing information which is considered by the Regulator as being equivalent to that of a Prospectus; (9) an Offer where the Securities are offered, allotted or to be allotted in connection with a merger if a document is available containing information which is regarded by the Regulator as being equivalent to that of a Prospectus; (10) an Offer where the Securities are offered, allotted or to be allotted in connection with a rights issue where: (a) the Securities are of a class subject to Reporting Entity disclosure; and (b) a document is made available containing information on the number and nature of the Securities including rights attaching to those Securities and the reasons for and details of the Offer; (11) an Offer where the Shares are offered, allotted or to be allotted to existing Shareholders free of charge or dividends paid out in the form of Shares of the same class as the Shares in respect of which the dividends are paid, and a document is made available containing information on the number and nature of the Shares and the reasons for and details of the Offer; (12) an Offer where the Securities are offered, allotted or to be allotted to an existing or former Director or Employee, or any Close Relative of such a Director or Employee, of the Issuer or a member of the same Group as the Issuer and: (a) the Issuer or the member of the Group already has its Securities admitted to trading on a Regulated Exchange; and (b) a document is made available to the offerees containing information on the number and nature of the Securities and the reasons for and details of the Offer; or (13) other than in relation to Debentures and Sukuk, an Offer in or from the ADGM which is directed at no more than 200 Persons that are not Professional Clients or Market Counterparties, in circumstances where the Securities are, or have been, offered within a Private Financing Platform or via a Multilateral Trading Facility.

question: When an Authorised Person needs to calculate E* for collateralised transactions that aren't OTC Derivative or long settlement ones, how should they handle the add on part?
answer: To calculate E* for collateralised transactions that aren't OTC Derivative or long settlement ones, an Authorised Person must follow a specific process. This involves using a formula that includes the fair value of both the Exposure and the eligible financial Collateral. Importantly, they must also calculate an add on amount to account for market and currency volatility. This add on can be calculated in two ways: either by using a formula that considers the net position in a Security and the appropriate haircut, or by using Value at Risk (VaR) models. If they choose the VaR model approach, they must first get approval from the Regulator. This ensures that the add on accurately reflects potential changes in market conditions, which is essential for maintaining financial stability in these transactions [#SRC:dcbb270d-c9cc-4b97-840b-71ad5f53c4fa] [#TGT:6705e521-28ce-43be-8404-ffdc3b3ba923].
source_passage_text: Calculation of E* for collateralised transactions other than OTC Derivative transactions and long settlement transactions. An Authorised Person using standard supervisory haircuts or own estimate haircuts under the FCCA must calculate E* for any collateralised transaction covered by a qualifying bilateral Netting agreement or qualifying cross product Netting agreement other than OTC Derivative transactions or long settlement transactions, using the following formula: where: E* = Exposure value after risk mitigation; E = fair value of the Exposure calculated in accordance with Section 4.9 of these Rules; C = fair value of eligible financial Collateral received; and add on = the add on amount to reflect the market price volatility and foreign exchange volatility, calculated in accordance with Rule A4.3.8 below.
target_passage_text: An Authorised Person must calculate the add on using one of the following approaches: (a) the approach according to the following formula: where: ES = absolute value of the net position in a given Security; HS = haircut appropriate to ES EFX = absolute value of the net position in a currency different from the settlement currency; and HFX = haircut appropriate for currency mismatch between the Collateral and Exposure; or (b) the approach using VaR models, provided the Authorised Person has received approval from the Regulator as referred to in Rule A4.3.5.

question: If someone wants to apply for a Financial Services Permission to deal with OTC Leveraged Products, what fees do they need to pay to the Regulator, and how does this compare to fees for changing an existing permission?
answer: When applying for a Financial Services Permission to handle OTC Leveraged Products, an Applicant must pay the Regulator an application fee. This fee is on top of any other fees for each Regulated Activity they plan to do. The fee is $5,000, or $40,000 if the products are for Retail Clients. On the other hand, if an Authorised Person wants to change their existing Financial Services Permission to add more activities or serve Retail Clients, they must also pay a fee. This fee is $5,000 for changes related to serving Retail Clients or doing Islamic Financial Business. So, while both situations start with a $5,000 fee, the fee for OTC Leveraged Products aimed at Retail Clients is much higher, showing the extra rules involved [#SRC:f02f1e7a-a3ea-47cf-94df-8656a695fbd0] and [#TGT:4b50eff1-6ea8-4b11-bead-95554b1f50de].
source_passage_text: Amendment of a Financial Services Permission other than the addition of a Regulated Activity (a) Subject to Rule 2.1(c), an Authorised Person applying to amend the scope of an existing Financial Service Permission to enable it to undertake additional Regulated Activities must pay to the Regulator such application fees as set out in Rule 3.2.1. (b) An Authorised Person applying to amend the scope of an existing Financial Services Permission to enable it to serve Retail Clients, other than pursuant to Rule 3.20.1, must pay to the Regulator an application fee of $5,000. (c) An Authorised Person applying to amend the scope of an existing Financial Services Permission to enable it to conduct Islamic Financial Business must pay to the Regulator an application fee of $5,000. (d) An Authorised Person applying to amend the scope of an existing Financial Services Permission through the amendment or removal of a condition, other than in accordance with (b) or (c), must pay to the Regulator an application fee of $5,000.
target_passage_text: An Applicant for a Financial Services Permission to carry on a Regulated Activity in relation to OTC Leveraged Products must pay to the Regulator, in addition to the application fees due in respect of each Regulated Activity which the Applicant proposes to undertake, an application fee of: (a) $5,000; or (b) $40,000 where those OTC Leveraged Products are to be offered to Retail Clients.

question: Under what conditions may the Regulator withdraw an Approval for a Controlled Function, and how does this relate to the fitness and propriety of the Approved Person?
answer: The Regulator is permitted to withdraw an Approval for a Controlled Function if it determines that the individual is not fit and proper to perform the function. This decision can be based on several factors, such as breaches of obligations, bankruptcy, criminal convictions, or findings that question the individual's integrity, honesty, or capability to manage affairs due to mental or physical incapacity. Additionally, the withdrawal can occur if the individual or their firm requests it. The Regulator's authority to withdraw such Approval is grounded in the need to ensure that only those who meet the required standards of fitness and propriety are allowed to perform Controlled Functions. This ensures that the integrity of the financial system is maintained and that individuals in these roles are capable and trustworthy. The Regulator's decision-making process involves assessing whether the circumstances align with the criteria that would render an individual unfit or improper for the role, as required [#TGT:3770f510-3010-431b-9ccf-af63b6825554] and permitted [#SRC:0f70ac0b-8f1a-48d4-83d8-35cd6b2b1dbb].
source_passage_text: Under section 46 of FSMR, we may withdraw an Approval given in relation to the performance of a Controlled Function where we consider that the Approved Person is not fit and proper to perform the Controlled Function in question. Circumstances where we might exercise this power could include where: (a) the individual is in breach of an obligation required by their Approved Person status; (b) the individual becomes bankrupt; (c) the individual is convicted of an offence or there is a finding against them that would be considered relevant to their integrity and honesty, or their ability to perform the relevant Controlled Function(s); (d) the individual becomes incapable, through mental or physical incapacity, of managing their affairs; or (e) the individual or the relevant firm asks us to withdraw the relevant status.
target_passage_text: Withdrawal of Controlled Function Approval The Regulator may withdraw an Approval given under section ‎45 if the Regulator considers that the person is not a fit and proper person to perform the Controlled Function in question.

question: Under what conditions must an Issuer seek subsequent approval for an issue of Securities that initially lacked approval, and how does the lapse of prior approval affect this process?
answer: An Issuer must seek subsequent approval for an issue of Securities initially made without approval under specific conditions. If the initial approval under Rule 9.7.5 lapses, the Securities can no longer be considered as issued with approval for the purposes of Rule 9.7.1. Instead, they are counted within Relevant Issues under Rule 9.7.1. To rectify this, the issue or agreement to issue must not exceed the limit set in Rule 9.7.1. Additionally, the holders of the Listed Entity’s Ordinary Securities must subsequently approve the issue. Furthermore, the Securities must be issued within three months from the date of this subsequent approval. This ensures that the Securities are treated as having been made with approval for the purposes of Rule 9.7.1, aligning with the procedural requirements [#TGT:3f609871-988e-4e0c-921f-6e1066c630f6] and addressing the lapse in approval [#SRC:76970fb8-577b-4a21-8996-4c8bde4ef2d2].
source_passage_text: If the approval under Rule 9.7.5 lapses, the Securities can no longer be counted as Securities issued with approval under Rule 9.7.5 for the purposes of Rule 9.7.1 above, and instead are to be counted within Relevant Issues under Rule 9.7.1.
target_passage_text: Subsequent approval of an issue of Securities. An issue of, or agreement to issue, Securities made without approval under Rule 9.7.1 is treated as having been made with approval for the purposes of Rule 9.7.1 if: (1) the issue or agreement did not exceed the limit in Rule 9.7.1; (2) the holders of the Listed Entity’s Ordinary Securities subsequently approve it; and (3) the Securities are issued within three months of the date of the approval.

question: If a Prospectus talks about Exploration Targets or similar things, what rules must it follow, and what must a Mining Reporting Entity do for its disclosures?
answer: A Prospectus that discusses Exploration Targets, Exploration Results, Mineral Resources, Ore Reserves, or Production Targets must follow certain rules, including Rule 11.2.1. It also needs to include details about how the Mining Reporting Entity handles environmental and social issues, the effects of its business on the environment and communities, and the risks it faces. At the same time, any disclosure by a Mining Reporting Entity that includes these topics must be prepared according to a Mining Reporting Standard and meet the chapter's requirements. This ensures that both the Prospectus and the disclosures are clear and meet the necessary standards for reporting mining activities [#SRC:ac70dcf0-7928-4d1c-9561-1b88ff273cb9] and [#TGT:5d4c0697-2ff8-49a4-9682-8e63acb63b9d].
source_passage_text: In addition to complying with the requirements of Chapter 4, a Prospectus: (1) that includes a statement about Exploration Targets, Exploration Results, Mineral Resources, Ore Reserves or Production Targets, must comply with Rule 11.2.1; and (2) must include details in relation to the Mining Reporting Entitys policies and practices in relation to operating in a sustainable manner, including: (i) the Mining Reporting Entitys policy with regards to environmental and social issues; (ii) impact of the Mining Reporting Entitys business practices on the environment and the communities in which it operates; and (iii) the environmental and social risks faced by the Mining Reporting Entity.
target_passage_text: Requirements for all disclosures. A disclosure by a Mining Reporting Entity that includes a statement about Exploration Targets, Exploration Results, Mineral Resources, Ore Reserves or Production Targets must be prepared in accordance with: (1) a Mining Reporting Standard; and (2) this chapter.

question: What details must a Recognised Investment Exchange make public regarding transactions in financial instruments, and how are deferrals defined in this context?
answer: A Recognised Investment Exchange is obligated to make public specific details about transactions involving financial instruments admitted to trading on or concluded within their systems. These details include those specified in a particular rule, indications of transactions determined by factors other than current market valuation, and any negotiated trade indications or amendments to previously disclosed information. The exchange must disclose this information either by referencing each transaction individually or by aggregating the volume and price of all transactions in the same financial instrument occurring at the same price and time. In this context, deferrals relate to the post-trade information that must be disclosed, including the trading day and time, instrument identification, unit price, price notation, quantity, and venue identification, if applicable. These elements ensure transparency and compliance with regulatory requirements, providing a comprehensive view of the transaction details as required [#TGT:26773b68-1f2d-4ec2-9bde-0271968ad33a] and permitted [#SRC:5f815122-ada4-4ada-9311-f869cdb31386].
source_passage_text: A Recognised Investment Exchange shall, with regard to Transactions in respect of Financial Instruments admitted to trading on or concluded within their systems, make public the following details: (a) those specified in Rule 3.6.7; (b) an indication that the exchange of Financial Instruments is determined by factors other than the current market valuation of the Financial Instrument, where the Transaction: (i) related to an individual Financial Instrument in a portfolio trade; or (ii) is a volume weighted average price Transaction. (c) an indication that the trade was a negotiated trade, where applicable; and (d) any amendments to previously disclosed information, where applicable. These details shall be made public either by reference to each Transaction or in a form aggregating the volume and price of all Transactions in the same Financial Instrument taking place at the same price at the same time.
target_passage_text: Deferrals. Post-trade information: /Table Start Detail Information (a) Trading Day The trading day on which the transaction was executed. (b) Trading Time The time in UTC (Universal Time Coordinated) or a time zone clearly identified to the user at which the transaction was executed. (c) Instrument Identification This shall consist of a unique code to be decided by the Regulator identifying the Financial Instrument which is the subject of the transaction; or, if the Financial Instrument in question does not have a unique identification code, the report must include the name of the Financial Instrument. (d) Unit Price The price per Financial Instrument excluding commission and (where relevant) accrued interest. (e) Price Notation The currency in which the price is expressed. (f) Quantity The number of units of the Financial Instruments. (g) Venue identification Identification, if applicable, of the venue where the transaction was executed. /Table End

question: What must an Authorised Person include in their Resolution Pack concerning Client Accounts, and how should they maintain these accounts?
answer: An Authorised Person must maintain a master list of all Client Accounts, ensuring it includes specific details such as the account name, number, location, and terms and conditions. This list must also indicate whether accounts are open or closed and include the date of opening or closure. Additionally, the Resolution Pack must incorporate records related to these Client Accounts, as specified in the relevant rules. This includes maintaining comprehensive records of Client classification, agreements, and the most recent reconciliations of Client Money and Investments. The inclusion of these records in the Resolution Pack is crucial for compliance with regulatory obligations, ensuring that all necessary information is readily available for review and audit purposes. By adhering to these requirements, Authorised Persons can effectively manage and monitor Client Accounts, thereby fulfilling their regulatory duties [#SRC:803ff2b9-9528-459a-b9d2-45066785e9f5] and [#TGT:47678f27-9e0b-4782-949a-f38e84a7442d].
source_passage_text: The following records must be included in the Resolution Pack of an Authorised Person conducting Investment Business: (a) Rules 2.7.1 and 3.7.1(d) (records of Client classification and Client agreements); (b) Rules 14.6.2 and 15.4.3 (master lists of all Client Accounts in relation to Client Money and Client investments); (c) Rule 15.4.4 and Rule 15.4.5 (adequate records and Client's written permission re use of Client Investments); (d) Rules 14.7.1 and 14.7.4 (assessment of appropriateness of Third-Party Agent and acknowledgement by Third-Party agent in respect of Client Money); and (e) Rule 15.5.1 and 15.6.1 (assessment of appropriateness of Third Party Agent and acknowledgement by Third-Party Agent in respect of Client Investments); and (f) Rule 14.11.1 and 15.9.1 (most recent reconciliations of Client Money and Client Investments).
target_passage_text: An Authorised Person must maintain a master list of all Client Accounts. The master list must detail: (a) the name of the account; (b) the account number; (c) the location of the account; (d) the bank, its address and contact information; (e) the account terms and conditions; (f) whether the account is currently open or closed; and (g) the date of opening or closure.

question: When can't the Regulator share a statement from an interview, and what must the Investigator do to make someone attend that interview?
answer: The Regulator is not allowed to share a statement made during an interview with law enforcement for criminal cases unless the person agrees or a law or court order demands it. This rule helps protect the person's privacy and rights during an investigation. At the same time, the Investigator can require the Person Under Investigation or others to attend an interview by sending a written notice. This notice tells them when and where to go and that they must answer questions. The Investigator can also ask them to bring documents, give information, help with the investigation, or allow the Investigator to visit their business to look at and copy documents. These steps ensure that the investigation is conducted properly while respecting the confidentiality rules that protect the individuals involved [#SRC:7585319d-2470-46fc-975e-d1a88a2805d6] and [#TGT:ba9deea1-694d-4225-bf79-201773a12046].
source_passage_text: In addition to the overriding duty of confidentiality set out in section 198, section 207(2) of the FSMR prohibits the Regulator from disclosing a statement made by a person to an investigator at an interview conducted pursuant to section 206(1)(a) to any law enforcement agency for the purpose of criminal proceedings against that person unless: (a) the person consents to the disclosure; or (b) the Regulator is required by law or court order to disclose the statement.
target_passage_text: The Investigator may, by written notice, require the person who is the Person Under Investigation or any other person (whether or not connected to the Person Under Investigation) to— (a) attend an interview at a Specified time and place and answer questions; (b) produce at a Specified time and place any Specified Documents or Documents of a Specified description; (c) provide such information as the Investigator may require; (d) provide such assistance as the Investigator may require; or (e) permit the Investigator to enter the business premises of such person during normal business hours for the purpose of inspecting and copying Documents on such premises.

question: When does money received under a Title Transfer Collateral Agreement from a Professional Client fall outside the scope of the Client Money Rules and Safe Custody Rules?
answer: The Client Money Rules and Safe Custody Rules do not apply when money is received under a Title Transfer Collateral Agreement from a Professional Client. This is because such money is not considered Client Money under the applicable definition. The rules specifically exclude the application of these regulations to Safe Custody Assets or Client Money held by an Authorised Person in the context of a Title Transfer Collateral Agreement. Therefore, when an Authorised Person holds money under these conditions, the usual protections and requirements of the Client Money Rules and Safe Custody Rules are not triggered. This regulatory framework ensures that certain financial transactions, particularly those involving Professional Clients and specific collateral agreements, are treated differently to reflect the nature of the agreements and the parties involved [#SRC:875ef4dc-f3c8-464c-b6f3-6216b864e3bc] and [#TGT:d541bbc2-9a05-45ff-8063-6dd671feecb7].
source_passage_text: In accordance with Rule 15.11.A.2 Money received under the Title Transfer Collateral Agreement from a Professional Client is not Client Money.
target_passage_text: The Client Money Rules and Safe Custody Rules do not apply in respect of a Safe Custody Asset or Client Money which is held by an Authorised Person pursuant to a Title Transfer Collateral Agreement.

question: If an Authorised Person doesn't meet the Combined Buffer Requirement, what actions can't it take, and what must it do before distributing profits?
answer: When an Authorised Person doesn't meet the Combined Buffer Requirement, it must not make certain payments or create obligations related to its capital until it calculates the maximum distributable amount and informs the Regulator. Specifically, it can't distribute CET1 Capital, create obligations for variable pay or pension benefits, or make payments on AT1 and T2 Capital instruments. Before distributing any profits, the Authorised Person must notify the Regulator and provide information about its capital, including CET1, AT1, and T2 Capital, and its profits. It also needs to calculate the maximum distributable amount and explain how it plans to use its profits, such as for dividends, share buybacks, or variable pay. This process ensures that the Authorised Person follows the rules and doesn't make unauthorized distributions [#SRC:30965fe8-bf1e-44f4-9cd5-7e9b5f84a81e] [#TGT:e6d646b8-b830-4640-a03e-fabef741c603].
source_passage_text: Restrictions on distributions. Where an Authorised Person fails to meet the Combined Buffer Requirement, it must: (a) calculate the maximum distributable amount in accordance with Rule 3.19.6; and (b) ensure that it does not undertake any of the following actions until such time as it has calculated the maximum distributable amount and notified the Regulator under Rule 3.19.7: (i) make a distribution in connection with CET1 Capital, or create an obligation to pay variable remuneration or discretionary pension benefits, or pay variable remuneration if the obligation to pay was created at a time when the institution failed to meet its Combined Buffer Requirement; or (ii) make payments on AT1 and T2 Capital instruments.
target_passage_text: Restrictions on distributions. For the purpose of Rule 3.19.3(b), where an Authorised Person intends to distribute any of its distributable profits or intends to undertake an action referred to in Rule 3.19.3(b)(i) or (ii), the Authorised Person must notify the Regulator and provide the following information: (a) the amount of capital maintained by the Authorised Person, subdivided as follows: (i) CET1 Capital; (ii) AT1 Capital; and (iii) T2 Capital; (b) the amount of its interim and year-end profits; (c) the maximum distributable amount calculated in accordance with Rule 3.19.6; and (d) the amount of distributable profits it intends to allocate between the following: (i) dividend payments; (ii) Share buybacks; (iii) payments on AT1 Capital instruments; and (iv) the payment of variable remuneration or discretionary pension benefits, whether by creation of a new obligation to pay, or by payment pursuant to an obligation to pay created at a time when the institution failed to meet its Combined Buffer Requirement.
