question: Under what conditions may a Customer and a Third Party Provider agree to a different time period for unauthorised or incorrectly executed Payment Transactions, and what obligations does the Third Party Provider have regarding liability for charges?
answer: A Customer who is not a Natural Person and a Third Party Provider may agree in writing to apply a different time period for unauthorised or incorrectly executed Payment Transactions. This agreement allows them to deviate from the standard rules concerning such transactions. However, the Third Party Provider remains obligated to its Customer for any charges the Customer is responsible for, as well as any interest the Customer must pay due to the non-execution, defective, or late execution of a Third Party Transaction. This liability underscores the importance of the Third Party Provider's role in ensuring the proper execution of transactions, even when alternative time periods are agreed upon. The agreement on time periods does not absolve the Third Party Provider from its fundamental obligations to the Customer regarding transaction execution and associated liabilities [#SRC:10510c2c-99d3-4cba-bac5-61cda5d00d44] and [#TGT:e704735d-e9c8-4326-b79a-28e066317151].
source_passage_text: Where the Customer is not a Natural Person, the Customer and the Third Party Provider may agree in writing that the following Rules do not apply: (a) Rules 20.2.15 and 20.2.16 (charges for information); (b) Rule 20.7.3 and 20.7.4 (withdrawal of consent); (c) Rule 20.8.2 (revocation of a Payment Order); (d) Rules 20.10.1 and 20.10.2 (requests for refund); (e) Rule 20.11.1 (evidence on authentication and execution); (f) Rule 20.12.5 (liability for charges); and the parties may agree that a different time period applies concerning unauthorised or incorrectly executed Payment Transactions for the purposes of Rule 20.10.1.
target_passage_text: Third Party Provider’s liability for unauthorised Third Party Transactions. A Third Party Provider is liable to its Customer for any charges for which the Customer is responsible and any interest which the Customer must pay as a consequence of the non-execution, defective or late execution of a Third Party Transaction by the Third Party Provider.

question: When can the Payment Service User and the Payment Service Provider decide to change some rules, and what happens if the Provider doesn't give the right transaction info?
answer: The Payment Service User, if they are not a Natural Person, and the Payment Service Provider can agree in writing to change certain rules. These rules include those about charges for information, consent withdrawal, and refund requests. They can also agree on different time periods for dealing with unauthorised or incorrect transactions. However, if the Payment Service Provider does not provide the necessary transaction information, the Payment Service User can still seek compensation under the rules. This right to compensation is valid even if the Payment Service User did not notify the Payment Service Provider within the usual time limits. This ensures that the Payment Service User's rights are protected, even if they have agreed to change some rules with the Provider [#TGT:82c7349e-fc45-46c6-adc3-d75ea1094bd4] and have the permission to do so [#SRC:95fa60a1-7e5a-4d8c-ad0f-194df6db4297].
source_passage_text: Where the Payment Service User is not a Natural Person, the Payment Service User and the Payment Service Provider may agree in writing the following Rules do not apply: (a) Rules 19.2.16 and 19.2.17 (charges for information); (b) Rule 19.10.1 (3) and (4) (withdrawal of consent); (c) Rule 19.18.1 (evidence on authentication and execution); (d) Rule 19.20.1 (Payer or Payees liability for unauthorised transactions); (e) Rules 19.17.1 and 19.17.2 (requests for refund); (f) Rule 19.14.3 (revocation of a Payment Order); (g) Rule 19.21.2 (defective execution of Payer-initiated transactions); (h) Rule 19.21.3 (defective execution of Payee-initiated transactions); (i) Rule 19.21.5 (liability for charges); and the parties may agree that a different time period applies concerning unauthorised or incorrectly executed Payment Transactions for the purposes of Rule 19.17.1.
target_passage_text: Where the Payment Service Provider has failed to provide or make available information concerning the Payment Transaction in accordance with Section 19.5, the Payment Service User is entitled to redress under the Rules in this Chapter notwithstanding that the Payment Service User has failed to notify the Payment Service Provider within the time period stated in Rule 19.17.1.

question: How should the annual designation fee be calculated and paid, and what is the deadline for the initial payment?
answer: The annual designation fee should be calculated based on how many months are left until the end of the year. This means the fee is adjusted to reflect only the remaining months. Once calculated, the initial annual fee must be paid in full to the Regulator. This payment must happen within twenty days after the fee is due, and it should be adjusted for the rest of the calendar year. This ensures that the fee is paid correctly and on time, meeting the rules set out for such payments [#SRC:94b3f85d-c033-41a3-a884-c873899c049f] and [#TGT:b8f50488-8fd2-4f32-a6c6-d841b3c60c37].
source_passage_text: In accordance with Rule 1.2.2, for Rule 10.2.1(a) the portion due of the annual designation fee is to be based on the number of months remaining until the end of the calendar year.
target_passage_text: In regard to fees payable on an annual basis pursuant to these Rules: (a) the initial annual fee must be paid in full to the Regulator within twenty days of the date on which the fee becomes due, prorated for the remainder of the calendar year; and (b) subsequent annual fees for the period commencing 1 January are payable in advance and must be paid in full to the Regulator on or before 31 January of the calendar year to which the fee relates.

question: What sources should a Relevant Person use to check if a customer's country is low-risk for money laundering?
answer: When a Relevant Person is checking if a customer's country is considered low-risk for money laundering, they must look at several factors. These include whether the country is recognized by credible sources as having strong systems to fight money laundering, low corruption levels, and consistent anti-money laundering rules with international standards. Credible sources for this information include reports from organizations like FATF, the IMF, the World Bank, and the OECD. These sources provide detailed assessments and follow-up reports that help determine the risk level of a jurisdiction. By using these credible sources, the Relevant Person can make an informed decision about the customer's risk level, ensuring they meet the necessary regulatory obligations [#SRC:0ab1cb10-020d-43a9-94ea-fd6de14133ff] and [#TGT:644bee29-fba0-448c-a5c0-c58e957e6e90].
source_passage_text: For the purposes of 7.1.3(1)(c), a credible source includes, but is not limited to, mutual evaluations, detailed assessment reports or follow-up reports issued by FATF, the IMF, the World Bank, the OECD and other International Organisations.
target_passage_text: When undertaking a risk-based assessment of a customer and considering whether or not to assign a low-risk rating under ‎7.1.1(1), a Relevant Person must take into account all relevant risk factors that would reasonably apply to the customer, including but not limited to: (a) customer risk factors, including whether the customer is: (i) a public body or a publicly owned enterprise; (ii) resident, established, registered or conducts business in a geographical area or jurisdiction of lower risk (as set out in paragraph (c)); (iii) an Authorised Person or Recognised Body; (iv) a Regulated Financial Institution that is subject to regulation and supervision, including AML/TFS regulation and supervision, in a jurisdiction with AML/TFS regulations that are equivalent to the standards set out in the FATF Recommendations; (v) a Subsidiary of a Regulated Financial Institution referred to in (iv), if the law that applies to the Parent ensures that the Subsidiary also observes the same AML/TFS standards as its Parent; (vi) a company whose Securities are listed by the Regulator, another Financial Services Regulator or a Regulated Exchange, which is subject to disclosure obligations broadly equivalent to those set out in the Market Rules; (vii) a law firm, notary firm or other legal business that carries on its business in the ADGM; (viii) an accounting firm, insolvency firm, auditor or other audit firm that carries on its business in the ADGM; (b) product, service, transaction or delivery channel risk factors, including whether the product or service is: (i) a Contract of Insurance which is non-life insurance; (ii) a Contract of Insurance which is a life insurance product with no investment return or redemption or surrender value; (iii) an insurance policy for a pension scheme that does not provide for an early surrender option, and cannot be used as collateral; (iv) a pension, superannuation or similar scheme that satisfies the following conditions: (A) the scheme provides retirement benefits to employees; (B) contributions to the scheme are made by way of deductions from wages; and (C) the scheme rules do not permit the assignment of a member’s interest under the scheme; (v) a product where the risks of money laundering are adequately managed by other factors such as transaction limits or transparency of ownership; and (c) geographical and jurisdictional risk factors, including whether a country or countries: (i) are identified by credible sources as having effective systems to counter money laundering; (ii) are identified by credible sources as having a low level of corruption or other criminal activity, such as terrorism, money laundering, or the production and supply of illicit drugs; (iii) have been assessed by credible sources, as having: (A) requirements to counter money laundering that are consistent with the FATF Recommendations; and (B) effectively implement FATF Recommendations.

question: What should a Listed Entity say in its annual report about following best practice standards, and what else is needed if they aren't fully followed?
answer: A Listed Entity should state in its annual report whether it has adopted the best practice standards. If these standards are not fully followed, the report must explain why and describe any steps taken to comply with the Corporate Governance Principles. The report should also include a statement from the Directors about whether they believe the governance framework is effective in promoting compliance, with any necessary details and qualifications. This ensures that the entity is transparent about its governance practices and efforts to meet the required standards [#SRC:129d03d7-18a7-46fc-853b-0f2c7c3c21b5] and [#TGT:5c3c0f6f-29a7-4b86-b0fe-109213900f3e].
source_passage_text: General. A Reporting Entity to which the Principles apply is required under Rule 9.2.10 to state in its annual report whether the best practice standards have been adopted. In circumstances where a Reporting Entity has not fully adopted or only partially adopted the best practice standards, it needs to explain in its annual report why the standards were not fully adopted or adopted only partially and what actions, if any, it has taken to achieve compliance with the Principles.
target_passage_text: Annual reporting on compliance. The annual financial report of a Listed Entity to which this section applies must: (1) state whether the best practice standards specified in APP 4 (the "Corporate Governance Principles") have been adopted by the Listed Entity; (2) if the best practice standards in APP 4 have not been fully adopted or have been only partially adopted explain: (a) why the best practice standards were not adopted fully or adopted only partially, as is relevant; and (b) what actions, if any, have been taken by the Listed Entity to achieve compliance with the Corporate Governance Principles to the extent the relevant best practice standards were not adopted, or were only partially adopted; and (3) include a statement by Directors whether or not, in their opinion, the Corporate Governance framework of the Listed Entity is effective in promoting compliance with the Corporate Governance Principles, with supporting information and assumptions, and qualifications if necessary.

question: What must an Issuer do about a Prospectus when offering Securities in ADGM, and what if there are changes or mistakes after it's issued?
answer: When an Issuer offers Securities to the Public in or from ADGM, they must publish a Prospectus as part of the regulatory requirements. This ensures that all necessary information is available to potential investors. If, after the Prospectus is issued, there is a significant change, mistake, or new important information, the Issuer or the person responsible must issue a supplementary prospectus. This new document should detail the changes, mistakes, or new information and meet specific requirements. These steps are crucial to keep investors informed and maintain transparency, as required by the regulations [#TGT:570827ee-e3f5-499b-8451-bbc5bdb6d80c] and permitted by the rules [#SRC:d7598df9-aeea-4b2d-b1ef-e4e98bea49dd].
source_passage_text: Regulatory treatment of tokens deemed to be Securities. The requirements for Offers of Securities fall under Sections 58 to 71 of FSMR and Chapter 4 of the Markets Rules (MKT). When an Issuer wishes to make an Offer of Securities to the Public in or from ADGM, these requirements include, for example, the obligation to publish a Prospectus under Section 61 of FSMR.
target_passage_text: Prospectus requirement. Obligation to issue a supplementary prospectus If at any time after the issue of a Prospectus there is a significant change in, or a material mistake or inaccuracy affecting any matter contained in the Prospectus or a significant new matter arises, the Issuer or the person responsible for the issue of the Prospectus shall issue a supplementary prospectus which— (a) provides details of the change, mistake, inaccuracy or new matter; and (b) complies with the requirements in section ‎62‎(1).

question: If an Issuer wants to offer Digital Securities, can the Regulator decide that something not usually a Security is one, and how do legal advisers help?
answer: Yes, when an Issuer wants to offer Digital Securities, the Regulator can decide that an investment not usually considered a Security is treated as one for regulatory purposes. This decision is made through a written notice and can include specific terms and conditions. Legal advisers play a key role in this process by helping the Issuer comply with all necessary regulations, such as the Financial Services and Markets Regulations (FSMR) and the Markets Rules (MKT). They work closely with the Financial Services Regulatory Authority (FSRA) to ensure that all Offer documents are properly drafted and reviewed. This collaboration ensures that the Issuer meets all regulatory requirements and that the Offer process runs smoothly. Legal advisers provide the expertise needed to navigate the complex regulatory environment, making their involvement essential for a successful Offer of Digital Securities [#SRC:a2de4d3e-7795-4d1c-b950-8cb4b9024c89] [#TGT:95497208-1e94-4b51-8ff3-d9e77f64177c].
source_passage_text: MARKETS RULES OFFERS OF SECURITIES TO THE PUBLIC Appointment of Legal Advisers Issuers seeking to make an Offer of Digital Securities should consider the appointment of suitable legal advisers, with the appropriate skills, knowledge and experience to provide the requisite assistance to the Issuer throughout the Offer process. The FSRA expects that such legal advisers would assist in ensuring an Issuers compliance with the applicable provisions of FSMR (including having the FSRA deem a Digital Security a Security under FSMR Section 58(2)(b)), and MKT (including in relation to the Listing Rules within MKT). The FSRA would generally expect to have direct engagement with an Issuers legal advisers throughout this process, particularly in relation to the drafting, and FSRA review, of Offer documentation.
target_passage_text: Without limiting the generality of its powers, the Regulator may, by written notice— (a) exclude the application of any requirements; or (b) deem any investment which is not a Security to be a Security for the purposes of these Regulations and the Rules made under these Regulations; subject to such terms and conditions as it may consider appropriate.

question: What actions must a Mining Reporting Entity take if its disclosure does not comply with a non-mandatory requirement in a Mining Reporting Standard, and how should this be explained?
answer: A Mining Reporting Entity is obligated to provide a detailed explanation when its disclosure does not align with a non-mandatory requirement of a Mining Reporting Standard. Specifically, the entity must include a statement within its disclosure that clarifies how and why the disclosure deviates from the non-mandatory requirement. This requirement ensures transparency and accountability in reporting practices, allowing stakeholders to understand the rationale behind any deviations. The explanation must be comprehensive, addressing both the nature of the non-compliance and the reasons for it, as required [#TGT:211edfe0-af57-41c8-84ca-814e1af3de0f] and permitted [#SRC:b8235755-7447-4ae5-b3dc-8cb14109c124].
source_passage_text: Rule 11.2.1(1) requires a Mining Reporting Entity to fully comply with all binding requirements set out in a Mining Reporting Standard. The Regulator also expects a Mining Reporting Entity to fully comply with all non-mandatory requirements set out in a Mining Reporting Standard, including, for example, Table 1 of the JORC Code or SAMREC Code, or explain its non-compliance in accordance with Rule 11.2.2.
target_passage_text: Requirements for all disclosures. Where a disclosure by a Mining Reporting Entity does not meet a non-mandatory requirement contained in a Mining Reporting Standard, the Mining Reporting Entity must provide in its disclosure a statement as to how and why its disclosure differs from the non-mandatory requirement contained in the relevant Mining Reporting Standard.

question: What steps must an Authorised Person take before offering OTC Leveraged Products to a Retail Client, considering the client's understanding of risks and potential losses?
answer: An Authorised Person must not offer OTC Leveraged Products to a Retail Client, or provide any advice or make arrangements on behalf of a Retail Client relating to OTC Leveraged Products unless it has first completed an assessment of the skill, experience, knowledge, financial resources and risk tolerance of the Retail Client. This assessment should ensure that the Retail Client demonstrates an understanding of the risks and potential magnitude of losses they may face. The Authorised Person should, prior to establishing a business relationship, consider whether the Retail Client has adequate experience and skill to understand the potential risk of loss involved in investing in OTC Leveraged Products. Additionally, the Retail Client must have liquid financial resources sufficient to absorb potential losses resulting from trading in these products. This comprehensive evaluation is necessary to satisfy the requirements imposed and to ensure compliance with the prohibition on offering such products without proper assessment [#SRC:e79e3adf-b4c6-4c32-81c3-6440c56574a6] and [#TGT:be7639eb-37d0-4a64-80e4-a7694dd68cc0].
source_passage_text: In order to satisfy the requirements imposed by Rule 23.5.1, the Authorised Person should, prior to establishing a business relationship with a Retail Client, consider whether such Retail Client demonstrates an understanding of the risks and potential magnitude of losses which they may be exposed to.
target_passage_text: An Authorised Person must not offer OTC Leveraged Products to a Retail Client, or provide any advice or make arrangements on behalf of a Retail Client relating to OTC Leveraged Products unless it has first completed an assessment of the skill, experience, knowledge, financial resources and risk tolerance of the Retail Client, such that the Authorised Person may reasonably conclude that the Retail Client has: (a) adequate experience and skill enabling them to understand the potential risk of loss involved in investing in OTC Leveraged Products; and (b) liquid financial resources sufficient to absorb potential losses resulting from trading in OTC Leveraged Products.

question: What does an Authorised Person need to do to control Liquidity Risk and meet the rules for management review and approval processes?
answer: An Authorised Person needs to have a system in their strategy that controls Liquidity Risk and helps them follow the rules in Rule 9.2.6. This system should allow the Governing Body and senior management to check if they are meeting the set limits and following the right procedures. It should also have approval processes, limits, and other tools to make sure Liquidity Risk management is done correctly. This way, both the strategy and daily operations for managing Liquidity Risk are covered, meeting the necessary obligations [#TGT:5c690bca-7ecd-4950-8e21-6c4cb9357647] and [#SRC:844184dc-c876-465f-8cc6-61d7c4911988].
source_passage_text: Controlling Liquidity Risk. An Authorised Person must ensure that the system referred to in Rule 9.2.1(5): (a) enables the Authorised Person's Governing Body and senior management to review compliance with limits set in accordance with Rule 9.2.7 and operating procedures; and (b) has appropriate approval processes, limits and other mechanisms designed to provide reasonable assurance that the Authorised Person's Liquidity Risk management processes are adhered to.
target_passage_text: The strategy must include a system for controlling Liquidity Risk which enables the Authorised Person to implement the requirements set out in Rule 9.2.6.

question: What specific information must a Third Party Provider make available to the Customer, and where must this information be accessible to comply with their obligations?
answer: A Third Party Provider is required to make available to the Customer the details of the dispute resolution services that can address disputes related to the rights and obligations under the relevant Chapter. This information must be presented in a clear, comprehensive, and easily accessible form. Additionally, the information must be made available on the website of the Third Party Provider, at its main office and any branches, and included in the general terms and conditions of the Governing Contract. This ensures that Customers have multiple avenues to access the necessary information regarding dispute resolution services, thereby fulfilling the Third Party Provider's obligations as required [#TGT:08650621-06b8-481f-8650-2c5ebdb06be0] and permitted [#SRC:055fc91a-22c6-4511-9508-b90212a4d414].
source_passage_text: The information to be made available under Rule 20.13.3 must be made available: (a) on the website of the Third Party Provider; (b) at the main office and any branches of the Third Party Provider; and (c) in the general terms and conditions of the Governing Contract.
target_passage_text: A Third Party Provider must make available to the Customer the details of the dispute resolution services able to deal with disputes concerning the rights and obligations arising under this Chapter in a clear, comprehensive and easily accessible form.

question: Under what conditions must a Recognised Investment Exchange not allow the trading of Securities on its facilities?
answer: A Recognised Investment Exchange is prohibited from permitting the trading of Securities on its facilities unless those Securities are both admitted to and not suspended from the Official List. This requirement is in place to ensure that only Securities meeting specific regulatory standards are traded, thereby maintaining market integrity. The prohibition applies unless otherwise prescribed by the Rules made by the Regulator, providing a potential exception to this general rule. This aligns with the requirement that an Issuer must have an Approved Prospectus for the Securities to be admitted to trading, ensuring that all necessary disclosures and approvals are in place. Therefore, the trading of Securities on a Recognised Investment Exchange is contingent upon their compliance with these listing and prospectus requirements, safeguarding the interests of investors and the orderly functioning of the market [#SRC:1708447a-ed53-4ba2-977e-dab2f28f5481] and [#TGT:76d81d0b-f659-47be-bcb8-a99a24187cac].
source_passage_text: DIGITAL SECURITIES & TRADING VENUES Recognised Investment Exchanges (RIEs) Pursuant to section 50(3) of FSMR, a RIE shall not permit trading of Securities on its facilities unless those Securities are admitted to, and not suspended from, the Official List. Section 61(1) of FSMR is linked to section 50(3), such that an Issuer cannot have Securities admitted to trading on a RIE, unless there is an Approved Prospectus in relation to the relevant Securities. An Issuer therefore wanting to have its Securities traded on a RIE needs to have such Securities: a) admitted to the Official List of Securities (maintained by FSRA); and b) offered by way of an Approved Prospectus.
target_passage_text: A Recognised Investment Exchange shall not permit trading of Securities on its facilities unless those Securities are admitted to, and not suspended from, the Official List except where otherwise prescribed in the Rules made by the Regulator.

question: What steps must an Authorised Person undertake when they fail to meet the Combined Buffer Requirement, and how does this relate to the preparation and submission of a capital conservation plan?
answer: When an Authorised Person fails to meet the Combined Buffer Requirement, they are obligated to prepare a capital conservation plan and submit it to the Regulator within five business days of identifying the failure. This plan must include detailed estimates of income and expenditure, a forecast balance sheet, measures to increase the CET1 Capital, and a timeline for restoring the Combined Buffer. The plan should also contain any additional information the Regulator might require for effective consideration. This requirement ensures that the Authorised Person takes prompt and structured action to address the shortfall in capital buffers, aligning with the procedural steps outlined for capital conservation. The submission of this plan is critical for regulatory oversight and helps maintain financial stability by ensuring that the Authorised Person has a clear strategy to rectify the deficiency in their capital reserves [#SRC:27f9bf56-82e3-4122-9d99-41e44b5fee9e] [#TGT:7a946965-716a-431a-b643-57f91e0ff92e].
source_passage_text: Restrictions on distributions. An Authorised Person must: (a) in subsequently taking any of the actions described in Rule 3.19.3(b)(i) and (ii), after having calculated the maximum distributable amount and notified the Regulator, ensure that it distributes no more than its calculated maximum distributable amount; and (b) prepare and submit a capital conservation plan pursuant to Rule 3.19.9.
target_passage_text: Capital conservation plan. Where an Authorised Person fails to meet the Combined Buffer Requirement, it must prepare a capital conservation plan and submit it to the Regulator no later than five business days after it identified its failure to meet the Combined Buffer Requirement. The capital conservation plan must include the following: (a) estimates of income and expenditure and a forecast balance sheet; (b) measures to increase the CET1 Capital of the Authorised Person; (c) a plan and timeframe for the increase of CET1 Capital with the objective of restoring the Combined Buffer; and (d) any other information the Regulator might need in order to carry out its considerations referred to in Rule 3.19.10 effectively.

question: What steps should an Authorised Person follow to calculate Credit RWA amounts for securitisation positions with non Controlled Early Amortisation, and how do they find the right conversion factors?
answer: To calculate Credit RWA amounts for securitisation positions with non Controlled Early Amortisation, an Authorised Person needs to follow specific steps. First, they must apply the same procedures as outlined in Rules 4.14.59 to 4.14.61. This involves determining the investors' interest, using the correct credit conversion factor (CCF), and applying the risk weight for the type of exposure involved. The conversion factors are found in a table that shows different percentages based on how much the excess spread is compared to the trapping point. For example, if the excess spread is at least 133.33% of the trapping point, the CCF is 0%, but it becomes 100% if it is less than 50% of the trapping point. These steps help ensure that the securitisation positions are evaluated correctly for risk, following the rules for non Controlled Early Amortisation [#TGT:4d9fc00a-f7e0-412d-acec-28e4ff8eb7fe] and the calculations allowed for Early Amortisation clauses [#SRC:57dad5ac-2c8e-4599-8633-4258d6e56fa1].
source_passage_text: Calculation of Credit RWA amounts for securitisation positions subject to Early Amortisation clause. In regard to securitisation positions subject to an Early Amortisation clause, the Credit RWA amounts for an Authorised Person acting as the Originator are calculated as the product of the following: (a) the investors' interest; (b) the appropriate CCF (in accordance with the table in Rule 4.14.61); and (c) the appropriate risk weight for the underlying Exposure type.
target_passage_text: Non Controlled Early Amortisation. In regard to non Controlled Early Amortisation, an Authorised Person must apply the same steps as set out at Rules 4.14.59 to 4.14.61 and determine appropriate segments and apply the corresponding conversion factors as set out in the following table: /Table Start Non Controlled Early Amortisation Features Uncommitted Committed Retail Credit Lines 3 Month average Excess Spread CCF 100% 133.33% of trapping point or more 0% <133.33% to 100% of trapping point 5% <100% to 75% of trapping point 15% <75% to 50% trapping point 50% <50% of trapping point 100% Non retail credit lines 100% 100% /Table End

question: What makes a Prospectus an Approved Prospectus, and when is a reference to a Prospectus considered an Approved Prospectus?
answer: A Prospectus becomes an Approved Prospectus when it is approved by the Regulator according to the rules set out for this purpose. This approval means the Prospectus has met all the necessary requirements. Additionally, whenever a Prospectus is mentioned in these Regulations, it is usually considered an Approved Prospectus unless the situation clearly suggests something different. This means that the approval by the Regulator is a key step in making a Prospectus officially recognized, and any mention of a Prospectus is generally assumed to be referring to an Approved Prospectus unless stated otherwise. This helps ensure that all references to a Prospectus are understood to mean an Approved Prospectus, providing clarity and consistency in how the rules are applied [#SRC:46050c03-9b46-4978-8e85-9f828d8d4e60] and [#TGT:caf92348-9f78-4a22-b449-0824165b55e1].
source_passage_text: An Offer document referred to in (1) is an Approved Prospectus for the purposes of section 61(2)(a) of the FSMR where it has been approved by the Regulator in accordance with the requirements in this Rule.
target_passage_text: For the purposes of subsection ‎(1)— (a) a Prospectus is an Approved Prospectus if it is approved by the Regulator in accordance with the requirements prescribed in the Rules; and (b) a reference to a Prospectus made by or under these Regulations is a reference to an Approved Prospectus, unless the context requires otherwise.

question: How must an Authorised Person proceed to recognise the effect of eligible financial Collateral for an SFT when the pre-settlement Counterparty Exposure is determined under specific rules, and the SFT is covered by a qualifying bilateral Netting agreement using the FCCA?
answer: An Authorised Person that has taken eligible financial Collateral for a Securities Financing Transaction (SFT) must follow a specific procedure to recognise the effect of such Collateral. If the pre-settlement Counterparty Exposure is determined according to certain rules, and the SFT is covered by a qualifying bilateral Netting agreement using the FCCA, the Authorised Person must calculate E* for all its Credit Risk (CR) Exposures to any single Counterparty covered by the agreement. This calculation should be in accordance with the applicable rules, particularly if the Authorised Person is using supervisory haircuts or own estimate haircuts. The calculated E* must then be substituted for E when determining the Credit Risk weighted Exposure amount for its CR Exposures to that Counterparty. This ensures that the effect of the eligible financial Collateral is appropriately recognised as required [#TGT:56e2cb44-f613-4f2a-bd4c-8726a79a5776] and permitted [#SRC:b2a0076b-8f51-4fc4-ac5b-6df2d25c4778].
source_passage_text: Measurement of E for pre settlement Counterparty Exposures arising from SFTs. An Authorised Person which has taken eligible financial Collateral for any SFT where the pre settlement Counterparty Exposure is determined in accordance with Rule 4.9.15 may recognise the effect of such Collateral in accordance with Rules 4.9.17 to 4.9.20.
target_passage_text: Measurement of E for pre settlement Counterparty Exposures arising from SFTs. An Authorised Person which has taken eligible financial Collateral for an SFT that is covered by a qualifying bilateral Netting agreement and using the FCCA, must calculate E* for all its CR Exposures to any single Counterparty covered by the qualifying bilateral Netting agreement, in accordance with Rules A4.3.2 to A4.3.6 in App4 (if the Authorised Person is using supervisory haircuts or own estimate haircuts), and substitute E* for E when calculating the Credit Risk weighted Exposure amount for its CR Exposures to that Counterparty under Section 4.8.

question: How often must an Authorised Person check its interest rate risk from Non Trading Book activities, and what must it do if it has positions in different currencies?
answer: An Authorised Person must carry out an evaluation of its Exposure to the interest rate risk arising from its Non Trading Book activities at least once a year. If the Authorised Person has balance sheet positions in different currencies, it must also measure its risk Exposures in each of the material currencies. This ensures that the evaluation is thorough and considers all relevant currency risks, helping to manage potential financial impacts effectively [#SRC:aac1f0b1-dd75-472e-9e45-c806fdf2a3f5] and [#TGT:9f5db2ba-19a5-4149-b8c0-f470ec9e54e3].

An Authorised Person with balance sheet positions in different currencies must measure its risk Exposures in each of the material currencies.

question: When must an MTF or OTF provide satisfactory arrangements to the FSRA for using a Spot Commodity Settlement Facility, and how does this relate to a Recognised Clearing House's compliance with Recognition Requirements?
answer: An MTF or OTF is required to provide the FSRA with satisfactory arrangements when it engages or proposes to engage a Spot Commodity Settlement Facility (SCSF) for settlement purposes. These arrangements must ensure that the SCSF complies with the relevant regulatory requirements, specifically those that would apply to a Recognised Clearing House (RCH), with necessary adaptations. However, it is important to note that a Recognised Clearing House will not be deemed non-compliant with the Recognition Requirement simply because it cannot arrange for a specific transaction to be settled. This implies that while the MTF or OTF must ensure compliance through proper arrangements with an SCSF, the inability of an RCH to settle a particular transaction does not automatically result in a compliance failure. This distinction ensures that the regulatory framework accommodates practical limitations while maintaining the integrity of settlement processes [#SRC:dd55d3d1-2eb7-4c91-ae7c-a494a1577f1c] and [#TGT:a15123d3-b822-401d-9551-e8759dd9e84e].
source_passage_text: REGULATORY REQUIREMENTS - SPOT COMMODITY ACTIVITIES Spot Commodity Settlement Facilities (SCSFs) Pursuant to MIR Rule 3.8.3, however, and in the context of Accepted Spot Commodities, an MTF/OTF must provide the FSRA the satisfactory arrangements made when such MTF or OTF does not engage a RCH (for example, to use in this context, when it has engaged, or proposing to engage, an SCSF). To clarify, the FSRA will require that arrangements to use an SCSF for settlement purposes will require the SCSF to comply with the requirements of MIR Rule 4.3.3 (with the references to a RCH being read as references to an SCSF).
target_passage_text: A Recognised Clearing House will not be regarded as failing to comply with the Recognition Requirement merely because it is unable to arrange for a specific transaction to be settled.

question: What does a Fund Manager need to do to start using passporting for a Public Fund, and what happens next?
answer: To start using passporting for a Public Fund, the Fund Manager must inform the Regulator that they want the Public Fund to be a Passported Fund. Once the Regulator gets this notice, they have five business days to tell the Host Regulator(s) in the places where the Fund will be promoted about the passporting intent. This is important to make sure the Public Fund is recognized as a Passported Fund in those areas. After the Host Regulator updates its records, the Regulator will update the Register of Passported Funds and let the Fund Manager know that the registration is complete. This ensures that the Fund Manager's plan to passport the Public Fund is properly communicated and carried out with the necessary regulatory bodies [#SRC:3c548ffe-2bd8-478f-8ddc-d55a1eb83d6e] and [#TGT:9ca2c478-4456-4c79-b447-743632309a37].
source_passage_text: The Regulator shall: (a) Within five Business Days of receipt of the notice set out in Rule 3.2.2, and subject to Rule 3.2.5, provide notice of the intent to use the passporting procedures under these Rules to the Host Regulator(s) in the relevant Host Jurisdiction(s) where the Passported Fund is intended to be Promoted; and (b) promptly following confirmation from the relevant Host Regulator that its respective Register of Passported Funds has been updated to include the details of the Passported Fund: (i) publish the details of the Passported Fund on the Register of Passported Funds; and (ii) notify the Fund Manager that registration on the Register of Passported Funds is complete.
target_passage_text: If the Fund Manager of a Public Fund wishes to use the passporting procedures under these Rules, it must notify the Regulator of its intention that the Public Fund be a Passported Fund.

question: When can the Regulator change an Approved Person's status, and what happens if they decide to take away the Controlled Function Approval?
answer: The Regulator can change an Approved Person's status if they haven't shown the needed skill, care, and diligence, or if their behavior doesn't meet the expected standards. If there are worries about their ability or suitability for the role, the Regulator might act, but only if these worries aren't serious enough to take away their status for not being fit and proper. If the Regulator decides that the person isn't fit and proper to do the job, they can take away the Approval given under section 45. This means the person can no longer perform the Controlled Function because they don't meet the necessary standards for the role [#SRC:61383442-b7af-4486-ab5c-610a613f73a2] [#TGT:3770f510-3010-431b-9ccf-af63b6825554].
source_passage_text: There are various circumstances that may arise where we may exercise our own initiative power to vary the Approval of an Approved Person, including where: (a) the Approved Person has not exercised the expected level of skill, care and diligence in carrying out the Controlled Function(s); (b) the conduct of the Approved Person is inconsistent with the requirements and standards expected of a person in their role; or (c) we have concerns about the Approved Persons ability or suitability to carry out the Controlled Function(s) as originally approved (but not such as to warrant the withdrawal of an Approved Persons status on the basis of fitness or propriety pursuant to section 46 of FSMR as set out in paragraphs 5.6.1 and 5.6.2).
target_passage_text: Withdrawal of Controlled Function Approval The Regulator may withdraw an Approval given under section ‎45 if the Regulator considers that the person is not a fit and proper person to perform the Controlled Function in question.

question: What must an Authorised Person that is a Domestic Firm do to maintain adequate Capital Resources, considering both the Individual Capital Requirement and the nature, size, and complexity of its business?
answer: An Authorised Person that is a Domestic Firm is required to maintain adequate Capital Resources by adhering to specific regulatory obligations. This involves ensuring that the Capital Resources are of the types and amounts specified in the relevant rules, and that they are calculated in accordance with these rules. Additionally, the Authorised Person must maintain capital and liquid assets beyond the basic requirement, which are adequate relative to the nature, size, and complexity of its business. This is to ensure that there is no significant risk of failing to meet liabilities as they become due. Furthermore, if an Individual Capital Requirement (ICR) is imposed, the Authorised Person must maintain additional Capital Resources as specified, in compliance with both the ICR and the general capital adequacy requirements. This dual obligation ensures that the firm is well-equipped to handle its financial commitments and regulatory expectations [#SRC:776c1fbb-de2a-4be6-b5fe-7b1666b6abff] and [#TGT:afbb9f59-2c26-47f6-ac38-4c36ecd40d56].
source_passage_text: Capital ratios. The Regulator may impose a further requirement, termed an Individual Capital Requirement (ICR), on an Authorised Person to hold additional Capital Resources arising from Pillar 2 adjustments (see Chapter 10). Where the Authorised Person has an ICR imposed on it, then the Authorised Person must, at all times, maintain adequate Capital Resources of the type and amount as specified in Rule 10.6.1 in addition to those kept to meet the capital adequacy requirements outlined in Rule 3.2.4.
target_passage_text: Domestic Firms – maintaining capital resources. An Authorised Person that is a Domestic Firm must: (a) have and maintain, at all times, Capital Resources of the types and amounts specified in, and calculated in accordance with, these Rules; (b) ensure that it maintains capital and liquid assets in addition to the requirement in (a) which are adequate in relation to the nature, size and complexity of its business to ensure that there is no significant risk that liabilities cannot be met as they fall due.

question: Under what conditions must an Insider refrain from dealing in Financial Instruments, and how does this relate to the legitimate performance of functions as a market maker?
answer: An Insider must refrain from dealing in Financial Instruments, Related Instruments, Accepted Virtual Assets, or Accepted Spot Commodities when such dealings are based on Inside Information related to these instruments. This prohibition is crucial to prevent market abuse and ensure fair trading practices. However, an exception exists for market makers. When a person acts solely in the legitimate performance of their functions as a market maker, dealing on their own account, this activity does not contravene the insider dealing regulations. This exception acknowledges the essential role market makers play in providing liquidity and stabilizing markets, allowing them to operate without the constraints that typically apply to insiders. Therefore, while insiders are generally prohibited from trading based on inside information, market makers are permitted to do so within the scope of their legitimate functions, ensuring their activities do not fall under the insider dealing prohibitions [#TGT:da3ba0b9-ff62-4830-a771-93c35b02af25] as required [#SRC:82586828-a155-4b3d-9f47-5207f5828538].
source_passage_text: Market making. Dealing undertaken by a person solely in the course of the legitimate performance of his functions as a market maker on his own account will not contravene section 92(2) (Insider Dealing).
target_passage_text: The first type of Behaviour is where an Insider deals, or attempts to deal, in a Financial Instrument, Related Instrument, an Accepted Virtual Asset or an Accepted Spot Commodity on the basis of Inside Information relating to the Financial Instruments, Related Instruments, Accepted Virtual Assets or Accepted Spot Commodities in question.

question: When Authorised Persons handle Virtual Assets, how should they understand the terms Client Assets and Client Investments?
answer: For the purposes of Rule 17, Authorised Persons who manage Virtual Assets should understand the terms Client Assets and Client Investments to include Virtual Assets. This means that Virtual Assets are treated like other investments, ensuring they have the same protections under the FSRA's rules. The FSRA has set this rule to make sure Virtual Assets are as secure as other financial products. This helps keep Virtual Assets safe and ensures they are managed with the same care as traditional investments. By doing this, the FSRA wants to make sure that Virtual Assets are handled properly, protecting clients and keeping the financial market stable. This approach is important for making sure that Virtual Assets are treated with the same seriousness and security as other types of investments [#SRC:15ac7d0d-8853-444c-8a24-8678075fa3c7] and [#TGT:1a0d0b8c-b8bf-48a1-b6ab-683d17ae56a0].
source_passage_text: AUTHORISED PERSONS PROVIDING CUSTODY OF VIRTUAL ASSETS In addition to having to meet the requirements set out in COBS Rules 17.1 to 17.6, Virtual Asset Custodians are required to meet the additional Rules set out in COBS Rule 17.8. COBS Rule 17.8.2 requires that the existing definitions of Client Assets and Client Investments be read to include Virtual Assets. This approach has been taken by the FSRA to ensure that Accepted Virtual Assets are afforded the same protections as other similar products and activities under FSMR and the FSRA Rulebook.
target_passage_text: For the purposes of Rule 17.8.1 “Investment” or “Investments”, (and, a result, the corresponding references to “Client Investments”) shall be read as encompassing “Virtual Asset” or “Virtual Assets”, as applicable.

question: What must an Authorised Person do to identify its capital instruments for inclusion in Available Stable Funding, considering the eligibility criteria for T2 Capital?
answer: An Authorised Person must identify its capital instruments for inclusion in Available Stable Funding by evaluating those instruments against specific eligibility criteria. This involves considering the capital elements that meet the requirements under various rules, including Rule 3.12.2, while excluding Tier 2 capital instruments with a residual maturity of less than one year. T2 Capital, in this context, consists of capital instruments that meet the eligibility criteria specified in Rule 3.12.3, along with related Share premium accounts. Therefore, the Authorised Person must ensure that the capital instruments identified for Available Stable Funding align with these criteria, ensuring they are eligible under the specified rules and not disqualified by maturity constraints. This process is crucial for maintaining the stability and compliance of the financial institution's capital structure as required [#TGT:2ba8da20-d967-4d1e-bf49-877f5e6ceddb] and permitted [#SRC:28d5816c-6e62-4526-954c-d1c4fa6f17d1].
source_passage_text: Available Stable Funding (ASF). Subject to Rule A10.4.6, an Authorised Person must identify its capital instruments that are to be included in its Available Stable Funding by considering the capital elements that are meet the requirements for eligibility under: (a) Rule 3.10.2; (b) Rule 3.11.2; and (c) Rule 3.12.2, excluding all Tier 2 capital instruments with residual maturity of less than one year.
target_passage_text: T2 Capital consists of the sum of the following elements: (a) capital instruments which meet the eligibility criteria laid down in Rule 3.12.3; and (b) the Share premium accounts related to the instruments referred to in (a).

question: Under what circumstances is a Mining Reporting Entity exempt from including certain forecast financial information in its disclosures, and what must be included when such exemptions do not apply?
answer: A Mining Reporting Entity’s disclosure pursuant to Rule 11.9.1 must include all material economic assumptions, a statement and explanation if these assumptions are commercially sensitive, and all other material assumptions. Additionally, it must include the Production Target from which the forecast financial information is derived. However, disclosure is not required to comply with Rule 11.9.2 when the forecast financial information is based entirely on Ore Reserves, or a combination of Ore Reserves and Measured Mineral Resources, or a combination of Ore Reserves, Measured Mineral Resources, and Indicated Mineral Resources, provided the Indicated Mineral Resources are not the determining factor in project viability. This exemption applies specifically to operating mines, thereby delineating the scope of required disclosures [#SRC:bf5c6652-b4c7-4b61-8732-68aed56e52a7] and ensuring compliance with the necessary obligations [#TGT:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489].
source_passage_text: A disclosure by a Mining Reporting Entity is not required to comply with Rule 11.9.2 where the forecast financial information derived from a Production Target relating to an operating mine(s) is wholly based on: (1) Ore Reserves; (2) a combination of Ore Reserves and Measured Mineral Resources; or (3) a combination of Ore Reserves; and (a) Measured Mineral Resources; and/or (b) Indicated Mineral Resources, provided that the Indicated Mineral Resources are not the determining factor in project viability.
target_passage_text: A Mining Reporting Entity’s disclosure pursuant to Rule 11.9.1 must include: (1) in relation to the assumptions used to determine the forecast financial information: (a) all material economic assumptions employed; (b) if the Mining Reporting Entity considers the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive, a statement to that effect and an explanation of the methodology used to determine the material economic assumptions; and Guidance A Mining Reporting Entity that considers certain information relating to the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive should refer to paragraphs 47-54 of the Guidance on Mining and paragraphs 127 and 128 of the Guidance on Continuous Disclosure. (c) all other material assumptions utilised. (2) the Production Target from which the forecast financial information is derived (including all the information contained in Rule 11.8.3).

question: What must an Authorised Person do to make sure their messages about Specified Investments or Regulated Activities are clear, fair, and not misleading?
answer: An Authorised Person must take reasonable steps to ensure that any communication they make to a Person about a Specified Investment or Regulated Activity is clear, fair, and not misleading. This means they need to check that the information they provide is easy to understand, honest, and does not give a wrong impression. This requirement is important because it helps people make informed decisions based on accurate information. It is part of the rules that keep financial markets fair and trustworthy. By following these steps, Authorised Persons help maintain the integrity of financial communications and protect investors from being misled. This obligation is in line with the broader regulatory standards that apply to financial communications, ensuring that all parties have access to reliable and truthful information [#SRC:48bcaa58-c3a9-4d7f-8042-bfb462cf2949] and [#TGT:a8ef44c9-fb33-4526-bbf5-6c7986418bb7].
source_passage_text: COBS Rule 3.2.1 requires an Authorised Person to take reasonable steps to ensure that any communication to a Person in relation to a Specified Investment is clear, fair and not misleading. Similarly, chapter 4 of MKT sets out the requirements on a Person who makes or intends to make an Offer of Securities in ADGM. Without limiting any requirements under COBS or MKT, the Regulator has developed the ADGM Green Bond Designation and the ADGM Sustainability-Linked Bond Designation to indicate that an ADGM Issuer is issuing a debenture that it asserts is in accordance with Qualifying Green Debenture Principles or Qualifying Sustainability-Linked Debenture Principles.
target_passage_text: When communicating information to a Person in relation to a Specified Investment or Regulated Activity, an Authorised Person must take reasonable steps to ensure that the communication is clear, fair and not misleading.

question: When might the FSRA charge extra fees, and what should an Applicant or Authorised Person do about it?
answer: The FSRA might charge extra fees when there is a big increase in the regulatory work needed, like when an MTF changes to a conventional Securities Recognised Investment Exchange. In such cases, the Applicant or Authorised Person should talk to the FSRA as soon as possible to understand the fee implications. Similarly, the Regulator can ask a Person to pay more if it expects to spend a lot more time or money on an application, authorisation, filing, or during ongoing supervision. Both situations involve extra fees due to more regulatory work, so it's important to communicate with the FSRA early to handle these costs [#SRC:43df6a6a-29a3-4dca-8203-57b209ce85cc] and [#TGT:64a0df5a-e946-4496-9fd3-244340c2a080].
source_passage_text: FEES Cumulative application of Fees Pursuant to FEES Rule 1.2.4, the FSRA reserves its right to impose additional fees in circumstances where a substantial additional regulatory burden is imposed on FSRA. In such circumstances, including the migration of an MTF to become a conventional Securities Recognised Investment Exchange, the FSRA recommends that the Applicant/Authorised Person discuss FEE implications with the FSRA as early as practicable.
target_passage_text: Supplementary fees The Regulator may require a Person to pay to the Regulator a supplementary fee in circumstances where it expects to incur substantial additional costs or expend substantial additional effort in dealing with an application, authorisation, filing or when conducting on-going supervision.

question: When a Mining Reporting Entity shares information about Exploration Targets or Results, what must they do to involve Competent Persons and get their approval?
answer: When a Mining Reporting Entity shares information about Exploration Targets, Results, or estimates of Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves, they must ensure that this information is based on details prepared by a named Competent Person. The entity must clearly state whether the Competent Person is their employee or a Related Party, or if not, who their employer is. They also need to mention the professional organisation the Competent Person is part of. Before making any disclosure, the entity must get written consent from the Competent Person(s) about how the information is presented. This consent ensures that the Competent Person(s) agree with the form and context of the information, which helps maintain the accuracy and reliability of the disclosure [#SRC:1133d38f-067b-4a0a-b325-b5c7b2512203] [#TGT:c30b96f6-edff-4774-b206-68a20fe00ba8].
source_passage_text: Competent Persons . Subject to Rule 11.12.2, a disclosure by a Mining Reporting Entity containing Exploration Targets, Exploration Results, or estimates of Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves must state: (1) that it is based on, and fairly represents, information and supporting documentation prepared by a named Competent Person(s); (2) in each case, whether the Competent Person is an employee of the Mining Reporting Entity or a Related Party and, if not, the name of the Competent Persons employer; and (3) in each case, the name of the professional organisation of which each Competent Person is a member.
target_passage_text: Competent Persons . The disclosure made in Rule 11.12.1 must only be made with the prior written consent of the Competent Person(s) as to the form and context in which the Exploration Results or estimates of Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves, as the case may be, and the supporting information is presented in the disclosure.

question: When a Mining Reporting Entity has already disclosed forecast financial information based on a Production Target, what must they include in any new disclosures if the Production Target involves an Exploration Target?
answer: If a Mining Reporting Entity has previously disclosed forecast financial information based on a Production Target, and the Production Target involves an Exploration Target, any new disclosures must include specific information. The entity must provide a clear statement about the Exploration Target's conceptual nature, indicating that there has been insufficient exploration to determine a Mineral Resource and that there is no certainty further exploration will lead to the determination of Mineral Resources or that the Production Target will be achieved. This statement must be prominent and close to the forecast financial information, as required [#TGT:8f759494-7a3a-4888-a07b-abac6b73113a] and permitted [#SRC:05f73fd5-8864-472c-bb5f-16a24a80dae4]. Additionally, the new disclosure should reference the earlier disclosure and confirm that the material assumptions from the initial disclosure are still valid. This approach ensures that investors are fully informed about the assumptions and risks involved in the forecast financial information.
source_passage_text: If a Mining Reporting Entity has made a disclosure under Rule 11.9.1, then any subsequent disclosure in relation to forecast financial information derived from a Production Target need not include the information in Rule 11.9.2 where the subsequent disclosure: (1) references the earlier disclosure that was in compliance with Rule 11.9.2; (2) contains a statement confirming that all the material assumptions in the initial disclosure upon which the forecast financial information derived from a Production Target is based continue to apply and have not materially changed; (3) if the Production Target upon which the forecast financial information is derived is wholly based on Inferred Mineral Resources, includes an at least equally prominent, and proximate, statement about the disclosed forecast financial information to the effect of the statement set out in Rule 11.8.3(5)(d); and (4) if the Production Target upon which the forecast financial information is derived is based in part upon an Exploration Target, includes an at least equally prominent, and proximate, statement about the disclosed forecast financial information to the effect of the statement set out in Rule 11.8.3(7)(b).
target_passage_text: A Mining Reporting Entity’s disclosure pursuant to Rule 11.8.2 must include: (1) in relation to the assumptions used to determine the Production Target: (a) all material economic assumptions employed; or (b) if the Mining Reporting Entity considers the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive, a statement to that effect and an explanation of the methodology used to determine the material economic assumptions; and Guidance A Mining Reporting Entity that considers certain information relating to the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive should refer to paragraphs 47-54 of the Guidance on Mining and paragraphs 127 and 128 of the Guidance on Continuous Disclosure. (c) all other material assumptions utilised. (2) if forecast commodity prices have been used in the determination of the Production Target, a statement that such forecast commodity pricing was arrived at on reasonable grounds. (3) the proportions of the Production Target based on: (a) Probable Ore Reserves and Proved Ore Reserves; (b) Indicated Mineral Resources and Measured Mineral Resources; (c) Inferred Mineral Resources; and (d) an Exploration Target. (4) a statement that the respective proportions of Inferred Mineral Resources and the Exploration Target (if applicable) are not the determining factors in the viability of the Production Target and do not feature as a significant proportion in the early mine plan; (5) if the Production Target is wholly based on Inferred Mineral Resources: (a) an explanation as to why the Mining Reporting Entity believes it has a reasonable basis for disclosing a Production Target wholly based on Inferred Mineral Resources; (b) the level of confidence in relation to which the Inferred Mineral Resources are estimated and the basis for that level of confidence; (c) a Technical Study of a sufficient level of confidence to support the Production Target, prepared by, or under the supervision of, a named independent Competent Person(s); and (d) an at least equally prominent, and proximate, statement to the effect that: “The level of geological confidence associated with inferred mineral resources is low. Though further evaluation and/or exploration work is required to establish sufficient confidence that the production target will be met, there is no certainty that further evaluation and/or exploration work will result in the determination of indicated mineral resources or that the production target itself will be realised. The mining reporting entity’s production target is based on its current expectation of future results or events, and should not be solely relied upon by investors when making investment decisions.” Guidance Any statement about a Production Target will be deemed to be misleading unless the person making the statement has reasonable grounds for making the statement. The Regulator considers that it is only under exceptional circumstances that a Mining Reporting Entity might form a view that it has reasonable grounds for a Production Target to be wholly based on Inferred Mineral Resources. (6) if the Production Target is in part based on Inferred Mineral Resources, an at least equally prominent, and proximate, statement to the effect that: “The level of geological confidence associated with inferred mineral resources is low. There is no certainty that further evaluation and/or exploration work will result in the determination of indicated mineral resources or that the production target itself will be realised.” (7) if the Production Target is in part based on an Exploration Target: (a) a statement of the factors that lead the Mining Reporting Entity to believe that it has a reasonable basis for disclosing a Production Target based, in part, on an Exploration Target; and (b) an at least equally prominent, and proximate, statement to the effect that: “The potential quantity and grade of an Exploration Target is only conceptual in nature. There has been insufficient exploration to determine a Mineral Resource and there is no certainty that further exploration work will result in the determination of Mineral Resources or that the Production Target itself will be realised.”

question: What must an Authorised Person that is a Domestic Firm ensure regarding its Capital Resources to comply with capital adequacy requirements, and what actions are required if it anticipates non-compliance?
answer: An Authorised Person that is a Domestic Firm must ensure that its Capital Resources always equal or exceed its Capital Requirement. This obligation is crucial to meet the capital adequacy requirements. The firm must have appropriate systems and controls in place to verify compliance with these requirements at all times. If the Authorised Person determines through these systems and controls that it cannot currently meet or is unlikely to meet the capital adequacy requirements in the future, it is required to immediately inform the Regulator. This ensures that the firm maintains adequate capital resources and adheres to regulatory expectations [#SRC:0d56af9f-7fc4-44a3-9bb7-147697b47f79] and [#TGT:fc38613a-248b-40ef-9af7-6cd69a5b516e].
source_passage_text: For the purposes of Part 2, an Authorised Person is required to have appropriate systems and controls in place to enable it to be certain that it has adequate Capital Resources to meet the requirements in Part 4 on capital adequacy at all times and to allow it to demonstrate that at any particular time if required to do so by the Regulator. Where through the operation of those systems and controls an Authorised Person forms the view that it does not currently or is not likely to be able to satisfy the requirements of Rule 3.2.3 in future, that Authorised Person is required to immediately inform the Regulator in accordance with Rule 3.2.5.
target_passage_text: Domestic Firms – adequate capital resources. An Authorised Person that is a Domestic Firm must have, at all times, Capital Resources which equal or exceed the amount of its Capital Requirement.

question: What should the Fund Manager do if there's a change or mistake that might lead to the Private Fund being de-registered, and what does the Regulator have to do then?
answer: If the Fund Manager notices any change or mistake that could affect the notification process before starting promotion in a Host Jurisdiction, they must quickly inform the Regulator in writing. This is important because such issues might cause the Private Fund to be de-registered if it no longer meets the legal requirements. Once informed, the Regulator must quickly pass on all important details about the change or mistake to the Host Regulator. The Regulator also has the authority to take necessary actions, including possibly de-registering the Private Fund from the Register of Passported Funds, if they find it necessary and appropriate. This process ensures that the Fund Manager stays compliant with the rules and that all relevant parties are kept informed [#SRC:05992880-f8db-4ec8-8e02-79ab08521207] [#TGT:001f1eee-febb-4f75-97f2-429cb0f2fdd6].
source_passage_text: If, as a result of any material change, error, or omission referred to in Rule 3.1.9, the Fund Manager will no longer comply with applicable legislation, including these Rules, or if the Regulator otherwise considers it necessary and appropriate in the circumstances, the Regulator shall take all due measures, including, if necessary, the de-registration of the Private Fund from the Register of Passported Funds in accordance with these Rules.
target_passage_text: If, at any time between the notification pursuant to Rule 3.1.2 and the commencement of Promotion in a Host Jurisdiction, the Fund Manager becomes aware of any material change, error, or omission reasonably likely to be relevant to such notification, the Fund Manager shall give written notice to the Regulator without delay. The Regulator will promptly provide the relevant Host Regulator with all relevant details of such material change, error or omission.

question: What should a Branch do to make sure it can pay its debts on time and follow its home regulator's rules?
answer: A Branch must keep enough liquid assets and financial resources to match the size and complexity of its business, ensuring it can pay its debts as they come due without significant risk. This involves managing liquidity by holding cash or assets that can be quickly sold, planning future cashflows, or borrowing if necessary. The Branch also needs to follow the rules set by its Home State Regulator and send copies of capital adequacy and leverage reports to the Regulator within ten business days after they are due. If the Branch expects or has any issues meeting these rules, it must inform the Regulator right away and provide any relevant documents [#SRC:456ed7d2-778d-4597-862e-2c4582c20c87] [#TGT:9fbb61f7-59fe-4340-85f8-ab6b9e7fb03c].
source_passage_text: In accordance with Rule 3.2.2 or Rule 3.2.4, an Authorised Person is required to ensure that there is no significant risk that liabilities cannot be met as they fall due. With specific reference to liquidity, an Authorised Person may meet its obligations in a number of ways, including: a. by holding sufficient immediately available cash or readily marketable assets; b. by securing an appropriate matching future profile of cashflows; and c. by further borrowing.
target_passage_text: Branches – general requirements. An Authorised Person that is a Branch must: (a) ensure that it has and maintains, at all times, liquid assets and access to financial resources which are adequate in relation to the nature, size and complexity of its business both as to amount and quality to ensure that there is no significant risk that liabilities cannot be met as they fall due; (b) ensure that it complies at all times with its Home State Regulator's prudential requirements; (c) submit to the Regulator a copy of every capital adequacy summary report and Leverage Ratio report submitted to its Home State Regulator within ten business days of the due date for submission to that regulator; and (d) in the event of any anticipated or actual breach of any prudential requirements set by its Home State Regulator, notify the Regulator immediately with any relevant documents.

question: How must an Authorised Person determine the measurement of E for pre settlement Counterparty Exposures arising from SFTs when eligible financial Collateral is taken and no qualifying cross product Netting agreement is in place?
answer: An Authorised Person must determine the measurement of E for pre settlement Counterparty Exposures arising from SFTs by considering whether eligible financial Collateral has been taken and if a qualifying cross product Netting agreement is absent. In such cases, the Authorised Person should recognize the effect of the Collateral as permitted by the relevant rules. Specifically, if the Authorised Person has lent or sold Securities with a commitment to repurchase, the measurement of E should be based on the latest fair value of the Securities. Conversely, if cash is lent or paid for the purchase of Securities with a commitment to resell, the amount of cash lent or paid should be used to determine E. This approach ensures that the financial impact of the Collateral is accurately reflected in the measurement of E, aligning with the procedural requirements set forth for managing pre settlement Counterparty Exposures [#SRC:b2a0076b-8f51-4fc4-ac5b-6df2d25c4778] and [#TGT:9578677d-803d-4f27-b8f6-2e4bdf56805e].
source_passage_text: Measurement of E for pre settlement Counterparty Exposures arising from SFTs. An Authorised Person which has taken eligible financial Collateral for any SFT where the pre settlement Counterparty Exposure is determined in accordance with Rule 4.9.15 may recognise the effect of such Collateral in accordance with Rules 4.9.17 to 4.9.20.
target_passage_text: Measurement of E for pre settlement Counterparty Exposures arising from SFTs. An Authorised Person must determine E, for a pre settlement Counterparty Exposure arising from an SFT which is not covered by a qualifying cross product Netting agreement as follows: (a) in the case where the Authorised Person has lent Securities to a Counterparty or sold Securities to a Counterparty with a commitment to repurchase those Securities at a specified price on a specified future date, the latest fair value of the Securities lent or sold; and (b) in the case where the Authorised Person has lent cash to a Counterparty through the borrowing of Securities from the Counterparty or paid cash for the purchase of Securities from a Counterparty with a commitment to resell those Securities at a specified price on a specified future date, the amount of cash lent or paid.

question: How much capital does a Recognised Investment Exchange need to keep, and how is this similar to what an Authorised Person must hold if they run an MTF or OTF?
answer: A Recognised Investment Exchange must keep enough capital to cover six months of its operational expenses. It also needs to have an extra buffer of up to another six months' expenses, unless the Regulator decides differently. This is similar to what an Authorised Person must hold if they operate a Multilateral Trading Facility (MTF) or Organised Trading Facility (OTF), where they also need to have capital equal to six months of operational expenses. This similarity ensures that both types of entities have enough financial resources to handle their operations and meet regulatory standards. By having these requirements, the regulatory framework aims to maintain financial stability and manage potential risks effectively [#SRC:59dfe046-0591-4dc2-a1d3-f4b1d56e6ee8] and [#TGT:1f2f00c6-1680-4516-adc8-b360f33ebe96].
source_passage_text: REGULATORY REQUIREMENTS - SPOT COMMODITY ACTIVITIES Capital Requirements The FSRA applies the regulatory capital requirements in COBS Rule 22.10 in two different scenarios, such that: a) where the Authorised Person is an MTF or OTF, the regulatory capital to be held (under COBS Rule 22.10.1(a) and MIR Rule 3.2.1) is equivalent to 6 months operational expenses ; and b) in relation to all other Authorised Persons, the conventional regulatory capital requirements applicable to the Regulated Activities undertaken apply.
target_passage_text: A Recognised Investment Exchange shall hold the following capital: (a) an amount equal to 6 months' operational expenses; plus (b) unless the Regulator directs otherwise, an additional buffer amount of up to a further 6 months' operational expenses.

question: Under what circumstances can communications be considered Exempt Communications, thereby not falling under the prohibition against making an Offer of Securities or having Securities admitted to trading on a Recognised Investment Exchange in the Abu Dhabi Global Market?
answer: Communications can be considered Exempt Communications when the Regulator exercises its power under section 59(c) of the FSMR to prescribe them as such. This designation means these communications do not fall under the prohibition against making an Offer of Securities or having Securities admitted to trading on a Recognised Investment Exchange in the Abu Dhabi Global Market. The prohibition applies unless the communications are provided for or permitted under the specific regulations. Therefore, if the Regulator deems certain communications as Exempt, they are not subject to the restrictions outlined in the prohibition, allowing for more flexibility in how securities can be offered or admitted to trading within the regulatory framework. This ensures that only communications falling within the defined scope of an Offer of Securities are restricted, while others, as prescribed by the Regulator, are exempted, facilitating smoother market operations [#SRC:0c1f16b4-30eb-4cf6-845f-2ecc45f1337f] and [#TGT:67094ff0-5048-4e6e-87e4-bb61836c324a].
source_passage_text: The Regulator has the power, pursuant to section 59(c) of the FSMR, to prescribe certain communications to be Exempt Communications. Such communications are not subject to the prohibition in section 58(1) of the FSMR as they fall outside the definition of an "Offer of Securities" in section 59 of the FSMR.
target_passage_text: A person shall not— (a) make an Offer of Securities in the Abu Dhabi Global Market; or (b) have Securities admitted to trading on a Recognised Investment Exchange; except as provided by or under these Regulations.

question: If a company is a Cell Company and also does insurance activities, what fees do they have to pay to the Regulator?
answer: A company that is a Cell Company must pay the Regulator $1,000 for each new Cell they want to add after they have their Financial Services Permission. If this company also does insurance activities, like making or managing insurance contracts, they must pay an extra $50,000 each year for supervision. This means they have to pay both the application fee for adding new Cells and the annual fee for their insurance activities. These fees are important because they cover the costs of adding new Cells and the ongoing regulation of their insurance work. So, companies doing both need to make sure they pay both fees to stay compliant with the rules [#SRC:31302f70-ed5e-4f1a-860f-140416c5d9e8] and [#TGT:6fc382ee-caf4-4abd-b571-718512a89e96].
source_passage_text: Cell Companies. An Authorised Person under Rule 3.11.2 or Rule 3.11.4 that operates as a Cell Company must pay to the Regulator an application fee of $1,000 for each Cell that it wishes to add after it has received its Financial Services Permission.
target_passage_text: An Authorised Person with a Financial Services Permission to carry on either one or both of the Regulated Activities of Effecting Contracts of Insurance or Carrying Out Contracts of Insurance as Principal must pay to the Regulator an annual supervision fee of $50,000 for either or both Regulated Activities.
